Cross-border criminal networks exploited systemic vulnerabilities in the existing VAT framework. The Parliament will discuss strengthening anti-fraud measures within the common VAT system to address these challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the quick reaction mechanism as a vital tool to combat large-scale VAT fraud, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and protecting public revenues.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 4 to mandate mandatory SME consultations during impact assessments, ensuring compliance costs remain proportionate for law-abiding businesses.  
EPP approves the urgency provisions in Articles 1-2, emphasizing their alignment with EPP’s 2012 manifesto priorities for EU financial stability and anti-fraud measures.  
EPP highlights the need for strict procedural safeguards in implementing the mechanism, particularly to prevent market distortions while maintaining single market coherence.  
EPP endorses the 2014 evaluation requirement as critical for refining the system, urging the Commission to incorporate real-time fraud pattern analysis for proactive adaptations.

EFD supports the quick reaction mechanism as a necessary tool against VAT fraud but advises that its application be strictly limited to proven cases of criminal activity to prevent overreach.  
EFD expresses concern that VAT's inherent complexity and regressive nature fuel systemic fraud, suggesting simplification of tax systems as a long-term solution.  
EFD recommends implementing the temporary exception mechanism with clear sunset clauses to ensure periodic review of its effectiveness and necessity.  
EFD cautions against expanding bureaucratic powers for VAT enforcement without proportional safeguards for businesses facing increased compliance burdens.  
EFD advises accelerating Council adoption of the mechanism while maintaining national flexibility to adapt anti-fraud measures to local market conditions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0428) concerning tax measures under Article 113 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, approving the proposal as amended and urging the Commission to revise its text in line with Parliament’s amendments under Article 293(2). It emphasized procedural accountability by calling on the Council to notify Parliament if deviating from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament should the Council propose substantial changes to the original Commission proposal. The resolution also instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and alignment in the legislative process.

title: Common system of value added tax and duration of obligation to respect a minimum standard rate: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax, with regard to the duration of the obligation to respect a minimum standard rate
background: The EU's transitional VAT system, operational since 1993, faced challenges including administrative burdens, cross-border trade inefficiencies, and fraud vulnerabilities, prompting repeated short-term extensions. With the minimum standard rate set to expire, the Parliament will discuss prolonging its application to maintain fiscal harmonization pending broader VAT system reforms.

stances.stance:
EFD partly upholds the minimum rate extension but demands binding amendments to overhaul VAT rules for cross-border trade by 2013.  
EFD argues the issue’s focus on rate duration fails to address systemic flaws enabling tax evasion, contradicting their core principle of rigorous fiscal integrity.  
EFD requests revising Article 1 to mandate a comprehensive VAT system review, prioritizing fraud prevention mechanisms over mere rate stability.  
The proposal’s legal certainty rationale overlooks EFD’s insistence on closing loopholes that legitimize revenue losses in international transactions.  
EFD warns that without structural reforms to application rules, extending the 15% rate perpetuates vulnerabilities inconsistent with their anti-fraud agenda.

SD fully sanctions the extension of the minimum VAT rate framework as a critical safeguard against fiscal fragmentation, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to EU-wide economic stability.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on harmonizing tax legislation, viewing it as essential to protect SMEs from disproportionate administrative burdens during transitional periods.  
SD highlights the urgent need to institutionalize an absolute 25% VAT ceiling across all Member States, reinforcing the issue’s goal of preventing austerity-driven overtaxation of citizens.  
SD strongly advocates for integrating anti-fraud mechanisms into the VAT strategy, a priority that the issue effectively advances through its focus on systemic coherence.  
SD emphasizes that maintaining the 15% minimum rate until 2015 provides vital predictability for businesses, directly supporting SD’s vision of a crisis-resilient single market.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0331) by approving the amended text, urging the Commission to revise its proposal under Article 293(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU to align with Parliament’s amendments. It demanded that the Council inform Parliament if it deviates from the approved text and reconsult Parliament should the Council pursue substantial changes to the Commission’s proposal. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to transmit its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural accountability and interinstitutional coordination while focusing on the substantive adoption and potential modifications of the legislative proposal.

title: European Banking Authority: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Banking Authority
background: The 2008-2009 global financial crisis exposed regulatory gaps in cross-border banking supervision within the EU, prompting the de Larosière Group's 2009 recommendations for systemic risk management reforms. The Treaty of Lisbon's 2009 implementation altered institutional decision-making procedures. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Banking Authority to strengthen EU financial oversight frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally supports the issue's insistence on maintaining subheading 1a priorities through strict MFF discipline, perfectly aligning with its fiscal responsibility doctrine.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for urgent MFF review under IIA mechanisms, echoing Danuta Hübner's call for eliminating "sub-optimal national approaches" through supranational crisis frameworks.  
EPP fundamentally supports leveraging IIA Article 47 for EBA's establishment, reinforcing Burkhard Balz's demand for supervisory authorities with "direct intervention rights" against fragmented oversight.  
EPP perfectly aligns with cross-border risk management priorities, operationalizing Theodor Stolojan's warnings about foreign bank exposures through issue-compliant supervision architectures.  
EPP fundamentally supports binding budgetary negotiations timeline, converting Enikő Győri's urgency for "compromise by September" into institutional implementation discipline.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the issue’s failure to mandate a unified European Financial Supervisory Authority with binding regulatory powers, perpetuating fragmented oversight inconsistent with crisis prevention.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal’s reliance on diluted intervention rights and capital requirements, which contradict their demand for stringent controls to curb financial market predation.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the prioritization of budgetary margins under subheading 1a over systemic reforms, overlooking the urgency of preventing economic collapse through robust regulation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s technical adjustments to funding mechanisms as inadequate to address the dominance of financial capitalism, undermining democratic governance and social stability.  
GUE_NGL highlights the absence of binding EU-wide rules as a critical flaw, rendering the Authority incapable of taming market excesses central to their anti-capitalist principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the financial sustainability of the European Banking Authority (Authority) within the existing multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2007-2013, noting that while the proposed reference amount for its funding aligns with subheading 1a’s budgetary ceiling, the remaining margin under this subheading for 2011-2013 is critically limited. It emphasized that new activities, including the Authority’s establishment, must not compromise other priorities under subheading 1a and reiterated its demand for an urgent review of the MFF by the end of the first semester of 2010, leveraging mechanisms under the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA), particularly points 21-23, to adjust funding allocations and ensure sufficient margins. The resolution stressed the application of IIA point 47 for the Authority’s setup and called for timely budgetary negotiations between Parliament and the Council to secure its financing. It further urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements are planned, ensuring transparency and institutional alignment.

title: European Securities and Markets Authority: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Securities and Markets Authority
background: The 2008 financial crisis exposed regulatory gaps in EU financial markets, where integrated cross-border institutions operated under fragmented national supervision, creating systemic risks. The Parliament will discuss establishing a centralized European authority to harmonize oversight and enhance financial stability.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely sanctions the issue's urgency in establishing robust EU-wide financial supervision, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to cross-border crisis prevention mechanisms.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for binding intervention powers for supervisory authorities, emphasizing the need to overcome fragmented national oversight structures as stressed in multiple debates.  
EPP fully supports attaching systemic risk monitoring to the European Central Bank's mandate, recognizing its proven crisis management capacity as highlighted by Mrs. Lulling.  
EPP absolutely sanctions the issue's timeline for operational authorities by January 2011, matching EPP's insistence on "reducing banking sector fragilities without delay" expressed by Mrs. Győri.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for eliminating moral hazard in cross-border bailouts, directly reflecting Mrs. Hübner's call for "cost-effective crisis handling excluding taxpayer-funded rescues."

GUE_NGL rejects the fragmented supervisory framework as totally condemning with their demand for a unified European Financial Supervisory Authority to curb market excesses.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s weak intervention rights, which fail to address the systemic risks of financial capitalism and contradict their principle of restoring political dominance over markets.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal’s inadequate capital rules, overlooking critical aspects of crisis prevention highlighted by industry leaders like Alessandro Profumo.  
GUE_NGL warns that the issue’s limited regulatory scope paves the way for future economic collapse, inconsistent with their mandate to protect social stability.  
GUE_NGL demands urgent structural overhauls to replace “parochial” compromises with binding EU-wide controls, rejecting incrementalism as antithetical to democratic accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the financing of the European Securities and Markets Authority, emphasizing that while the proposed reference amount aligns with the 2007-2013 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) ceiling for subheading 1a, the remaining margin under this subheading for 2011-2013 is critically limited. It stressed that new funding must not undermine existing priorities under subheading 1a and called for an urgent review of the MFF by the end of the first semester of 2010, utilizing mechanisms outlined in the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA), particularly points 21-23, to adjust budgetary allocations and ensure sufficient flexibility. The resolution highlighted the application of point 47 of the IIA for establishing the Authority and urged timely budgetary negotiations between Parliament and the Council to secure its financing. It further demanded that the Commission resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments are introduced, safeguarding parliamentary oversight.

title: European Semester for economic policy coordination: annual growth survey 2014: REPORT on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2014
background: The EU's economic governance framework, established through treaties and regulations, faced challenges from fragile post-crisis recovery, high unemployment, and structural reform needs, with the Europe 2020 targets at risk. The Parliament will discuss the 2014 European Semester and Annual Growth Survey, focusing on sustainable growth, fiscal consolidation, competitiveness, and unemployment.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on democratic accountability in economic governance, aligning perfectly with their commitment to enhanced parliamentary scrutiny of Troika operations and financial assistance programs.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for growth-friendly fiscal consolidation but proposes strengthening ecological priorities by mandating resource efficiency and carbon footprint metrics in macroeconomic assessments.  
GREEN_EFA completely approves integrating social indicators like poverty rates and educational spending into policy evaluations, which matches their manifesto demands for inequality reduction.  
GREEN_EFA approves the focus on sustainable energy investments and urges explicit mention of fossil fuel phase-out timelines to align with climate neutrality goals.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to formalize civil society participation in the European Semester process, suggesting amendments to institutionalize social partner consultations at national levels.

GUE/NGL absolutely challenges the issue’s growth-friendly fiscal consolidation framework, which conflicts with their rejection of austerity policies that disproportionately burden workers, pensioners, and the precariously employed. The party condemns measures like pension cuts in Portugal and Spain as systemic attacks on social rights.  

GUE/NGL rejects the structural reform agenda for perpetuating labor market deregulation, citing increased precarious work and wage suppression across the EU as direct contradictions to their demands for living wages and collective bargaining protections.  

The issue’s reliance on EIB financing and capital markets is deemed incompatible with GUE/NGL’s call to confront financial speculation and tax evasion by corporations, rather than transferring public resources to private actors.  

GUE/NGL challenges the Banking Union’s adequacy, arguing it fails to address Germany’s €180 billion trade surplus and other macroeconomic imbalances that exacerbate intra-EU inequality through export-driven dominance.  

The alignment with Europe 2020 Strategy targets is criticized as structurally reinforcing neoliberal governance, inconsistent with GUE/NGL’s insistence on wealth redistribution and public investment in universal social services over market-driven solutions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the fragile economic recovery in the EU, noting projected 1.1% GDP growth in 2014, persistent unemployment, and low inflation. It emphasized the need for growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, structural reforms to enhance competitiveness, and investments in innovation, education, and sustainable energy to achieve sustainable growth and job creation. The resolution highlighted the urgency of addressing youth unemployment through swift implementation of programs like the Youth Employment Initiative and improving SME access to finance via capital markets, the European Investment Bank (EIB), and innovative financial instruments. It called for stronger action against tax evasion, measurable targets under the Europe 2020 Strategy, and completion of the Banking Union to stabilize financial markets. The Parliament criticized the lack of ambition in the Annual Growth Survey 2014 and urged concrete proposals to leverage the EU budget for growth, including frontloading Horizon 2020, COSME, and Erasmus+ programs. Concerns were raised about low payment appropriations in the EU budget hindering economic recovery and the need for a reformed own-resources system to reduce Member States’ fiscal burdens. The resolution stressed democratic accountability in economic governance, advocating for enhanced parliamentary scrutiny of the European Semester, Troika operations, and financial assistance programs. It urged Member States to align reforms with Europe 2020 goals, address macroeconomic imbalances, and prioritize long-term sustainability of social systems, while warning against excessive debt and loss of global market shares.

title: European System of Financial Supervision review: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on the European System of Financial Supervision (ESFS) Review
background: The 2008 financial crisis exposed fragmented EU financial supervision, contributing to instability. Post-crisis reforms established the European System of Financial Supervision (2010) with three sectoral authorities and a risk board. Subsequent Banking Union creation introduced the Single Supervisory Mechanism, altering supervisory dynamics. The Parliament will discuss ESFS effectiveness, governance, and integration with evolving regulatory frameworks.

stances.stance:
EFD entirely challenges the issue's failure to confront Luxembourg's systemic role in enabling multinational tax avoidance through opaque financial structures.  
EFD rejects the ESFS centralization agenda as incompatible with national sovereignty over fiscal policy and financial regulation.  
The proposal's transparency provisions dangerously omit binding mechanisms to expose cross-border corporate tax evasion schemes.  
EFD condemns expanding EU supervisory powers while tolerating regulatory arbitrage via member state tax haven policies.  
 The issue's EU power consolidation directly contradicts EFD's manifesto commitment to dismantle Brussels-based financial bureaucracies.

SD strongly approves the issue's emphasis on automated data-sharing and independent budgetary provisions, which align perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to transparent, efficient financial governance.  
SD approves the call to integrate systemic risk warnings into the European Semester process, effectively advancing SD's priority of cohesive EU-wide economic oversight.  
SD endorses governance reforms such as streamlined decision-making and stakeholder engagement groups, reflecting their 2023 manifesto pledge to democratize supervisory frameworks.  
SD highlights the blue card response advocating automatic information exchange as critical to reducing operational costs and aligning with SD's vision for frictionless cross-border supervision.  
SD proposes amending Article 7 to specify quarterly public disclosures of ESRB risk assessments, ensuring transparency without opposing the issue's core objectives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the fragmented and inconsistent supervision of EU financial markets, emphasizing the need to strengthen the European Supervisory Authorities (ESAs) and the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) to address systemic risks, enhance consumer protection, and ensure a level playing field. It highlighted gaps in the ESRB’s capacity to monitor systemic risks, such as prolonged low interest rates, and noted its understaffing (with fewer than half the initially proposed staff), which hindered effectiveness. The resolution called for expanding the ESRB’s mandate to issue warnings to the ECB and national authorities, improving data-sharing standards across supervisory bodies, and establishing a single data collection point to reduce duplication. It urged reforms to ESA governance, including independent management boards, streamlined decision-making, and enhanced transparency, while stressing the need for ESAs to prioritize consumer protection, conduct cost-benefit analyses, and address regulatory overlaps. The Parliament advocated granting ESAs direct supervisory powers over pan-European entities, stronger investigatory mandates, and binding mediation tools to resolve cross-border disputes. It criticized the ECB’s dual role in monetary policy and banking supervision (via the SSM) for potential conflicts of interest and called for clarifying the ESAs’ role in the SSM framework to prevent regulatory arbitrage. The resolution also demanded better alignment of sectoral legislation, simplified reporting for market participants, and a review of the ESFS framework to assess the feasibility of a unified financial code or an Insurance Union. Finally, it emphasized the need for adequate ESA funding, gender balance in leadership appointments, and closer collaboration with international bodies to strengthen EU financial stability.

title: Credit rating agencies: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1060/2009 on credit rating agencies
background: Following the 2008 financial crisis and subsequent eurozone debt instability, credit rating agencies faced criticism for sovereign debt downgrades exacerbating market volatility. Existing EU Regulation 1060/2009, amended in 2011 to enhance supervision via ESMA, remained scrutinized for insufficient competition and oversight mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss regulatory reforms addressing market reliance on ratings and sovereign debt assessment practices.

stances.stance:
SD absolutely endorses the merger prohibition for rating agencies exceeding 20% market share, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to dismantle oligopolistic structures and stimulate sectoral competition.  
SD perfectly aligns with the roadmap for establishing a European public rating agency, viewing this as critical to achieving sovereign debt assessments free from private sector conflicts of interest.  
SD fully supports the liability regime and jurisdictional rules favoring injured parties, proposing future expansion to explicitly cover issuers as a logical enhancement to current accountability frameworks.  
SD endorses the ban on unsolicited sovereign ratings before major political events, effectively advancing SD's priority to prevent market manipulation through strategic timing of downgrades.  
SD aligns with the 2020 timeline for reducing regulatory reliance on external ratings, urging accelerated adoption of internal risk assessment capacities across financial institutions.

ECR rejects the proposal's creation of a European credit rating agency as antithetical to market credibility and taxpayer-funded inefficiency.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the "gagging" of rating agencies' warnings, viewing this as protectionist overreach inconsistent with free-market principles.  
ECR condemns attempts to impose eurozone crisis-management rules across all 27 Member States, warning it destabilizes the UK-EU single market relationship.  
ECR disputes the issue's premise that regulatory harmonization addresses sovereign debt crises, citing Greece's fiscal mismanagement as the root cause.  
ECR warns that bureaucratic rating agency rules risk replacing market accountability with administrative alibis, distorting risk assessment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal (COM(2011)0747) under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at harmonizing national laws for the internal market. It acknowledged the Swedish Parliament’s reasoned opinion challenging compliance with subsidiarity principles, alongside consultations with the European Central Bank (April 2012) and the European Economic and Social Committee (March 2012). The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts. It further instructed the President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with procedural and legal frameworks while addressing substantive concerns over regulatory coherence and subsidiarity.

title: Criminal sanctions for insider dealing and market manipulation: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on criminal sanctions for insider dealing and market manipulation
background: Following the 2008 financial crisis and high-profile market abuse cases like LIBOR, EU member states had divergent national laws and inconsistent enforcement of market abuse offenses, with some lacking criminal penalties. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing criminal sanctions for insider dealing and market manipulation to address regulatory gaps and ensure uniform enforcement across the single market.

stances.stance:
EFD partially agrees the directive but requests revisions to address state-level complicity, highlighting Bulgaria's experience where insider information leaks from government institutions during public tenders.  
EFD urges amendments to harmonize legal definitions of insider trading across member states, noting current discrepancies undermine cross-border enforcement effectiveness.  
EFD fundamentally questions the proposal's ability to hold high-ranking financial officials accountable, citing unresolved concerns about ECB leadership's role in past banking scandals.  
EFD proposes setting EU-wide minimum maximum penalties for market manipulation to prevent jurisdictional arbitrage, referencing speculative derivative trading damages.  
EFD requests enhanced oversight mechanisms for member states with documented governance failures, arguing the current text overlooks corruption risks in national implementation.

GREEN_EFA absolutely sanctions the issue's establishment of robust sanctions as a critical step toward deterring financial crimes, perfectly aligning with their commitment to stringent market regulation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on justice and morality in financial systems, echoing their long-standing advocacy for ethical economic practices.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the zero-tolerance approach to market manipulation, recognizing its congruence with their manifesto priorities for combating corporate impunity.  
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s political message of holding financial actors accountable, viewing it as essential to restoring public trust in EU institutions.  
GREEN_EFA commends the cross-institutional courage demonstrated in advancing this directive, affirming its role in transforming the EU into a guardian of financial integrity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0654) and its amended version (COM(2012)0420) aimed at strengthening criminal sanctions for market abuse under Article 83(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution emphasized compliance with subsidiarity principles, addressing a reasoned objection from the German Bundesrat that questioned the proposal’s alignment with EU competence limits. It incorporated opinions from the European Central Bank (March 2012) and the European Economic and Social Committee (March 2012), which supported harmonized penalties to deter insider trading and market manipulation. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to maintain the proposal’s integrity or re-submit it if substantially altered, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring cross-border enforcement consistency while respecting legal frameworks.

title: Deposit guarantee schemes: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on Deposit Guarantee Schemes (recast)
background: The 2008 financial crisis revealed vulnerabilities in EU banking systems, including inconsistent national deposit protection levels and insufficient safeguards against bank failures, prompting the European Commission to propose reforms in 2010. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing deposit guarantee schemes to strengthen financial stability and depositor protection across member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the harmonization of deposit guarantee coverage levels across the EU, aligning with their commitment to equitable consumer protection and financial market stability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on risk-adjusted bank contributions to DGS funds, which mirrors their longstanding advocacy for proportional accountability in financial sector reforms.  
GREEN_EFA urges enhancing Article 6 to mandate <72-hour reimbursement timelines> rather than flexible windows, ensuring swift depositor access during crises without opposing the core reimbursement framework.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Clause 12 to require EBA oversight of cross-border DGS linkages, strengthening supranational accountability while preserving voluntary cooperation mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to explicitly tie bank capital requirements to lending practices in Annex III, addressing concerns about speculative financial activities diverting funds from real economic needs.

ECR rejects the mandatory 1.5% pre-funded deposit requirement as fully condemning with national banking market realities, particularly for economies dominated by large institutions.  
ECR opposes the directive's inflexible funding structure that would divert €15+ billion from business lending in concentrated markets like the UK, undermining economic recovery.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the issue's one-size-fits-all approach, demanding recognition of proven national alternatives like ring-fencing and retrospective capital calls.  
ECR condemns unlimited sovereign debt investments in DGS funds as creating perverse incentives while failing to address systemic banking concentration risks.  
ECR challenges the harmonization model for overlooking critical aspects of cross-border stability, advocating instead for voluntary linkages preserving national adaptation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for harmonized Deposit Guarantee Schemes (DGS) across the EU to ensure comprehensive depositor protection, financial stability, and prevention of market distortions. The resolution emphasized establishing common requirements for DGS, including uniform coverage levels, realistic time limits for reimbursements, and flexibility for member states to adapt schemes to national financial market conditions while maintaining core standards. It advocated voluntary cross-border DGS or linkages between national schemes to enhance the internal market, with supervision by the European Banking Authority (EBA) in cooperation with national authorities. The resolution stressed the importance of aligning DGS operational areas with the economic costs of bank failures, ensuring balanced and stable cross-border schemes, and facilitating depositor access to foreign credit institution branches. It highlighted cooperation between national DGS to streamline depositor interactions and enable voluntary cross-border credit provision. By standardizing key elements like coverage, reimbursement timelines, and fund usage terms, the resolution aimed to achieve depositor protection, financial system stability, and equitable competition, while allowing member states flexibility to tailor schemes to national contexts.

title: Monitoring and assessing draft budgetary plans and ensuring the correction of excessive deficit of the Member States in the euro area: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common provisions for monitoring and assessing draft budgetary plans and ensuring the correction of excessive deficit of the Member States in the euro area
background: The euro area faced prolonged financial instability and sovereign debt crises, exposing gaps in EU economic governance frameworks to preemptively address fiscal imbalances and coordinate budgetary oversight among member states. The Parliament will discuss enhanced surveillance mechanisms and corrective measures for eurozone states' draft budgetary plans and excessive deficit procedures.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the integration of binding fiscal rules and automatic correction mechanisms into EU legislation, aligning with their commitment to budgetary discipline and the Stability and Growth Pact.  
EPP approves the dual focus on financial stability and sustainable growth, emphasizing that structural reforms rather than new debt instruments form the foundation for economic recovery.  
EPP endorses enhanced Commission surveillance powers under the community method while insisting on maintaining national parliamentary sovereignty in budgetary processes.  
EPP proposes clarifying funding sources for any future financial mechanisms, ensuring transparency in implementation without opposing the growth-oriented provisions.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of strict debt reduction timelines and rejects debt mutualization instruments that conflict with Treaty obligations under Article 125 TFEU.

GUE/NGL rejects fundamentally the undemocratic imposition of austerity through enhanced surveillance mechanisms that strip Member States of economic sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL opposes the legalization of creditor-protection schemes that prioritize debt repayment over public investment in social services and employment.  
GUE/NGL condemns the institutionalization of failed austerity policies under the guise of "macro-economic adjustment programmes," which directly contradict demands for growth-centered alternatives.  
GUE/NGL challenges the legal legitimacy of incorporating the Fiscal Compact’s logic into EU law, bypassing democratic ratification processes and entrenching neoliberal governance.  
GUE/NGL denounces the "two-pack" as a continuation of anti-democratic EU interventions that deepen recession and unemployment while shielding financial elites from crisis consequences.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0821) on economic governance, emphasizing compliance with subsidiarity principles following objections from the Swedish Parliament and French Senate. It considered the European Central Bank’s March 2012 opinion and reports from its Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (A7-0173/2012) and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading position, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The decision referenced Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provisions (Articles 121(6), 136, and 294) but focused on ensuring alignment with legal and procedural frameworks while addressing subsidiarity challenges.

title: Framework for the recovery and resolution of credit institutions and investment firms: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for the recovery and resolution of credit institutions and investment firms and amending Council Directives 77/91/EEC and 82/891/EC, Directives 2001/24/EC, 2002/47/EC, 2004/25/EC, 2005/56/EC, 2007/36/EC and 2011/35/EC and Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010
background: The 2008 financial crisis exposed systemic risks in EU banking sectors, with taxpayer-funded bailouts and cross-border instability highlighting fragmented national resolution frameworks and insufficient mechanisms to manage failing banks. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing rules for credit institutions' recovery/resolution to prevent future crises and protect financial stability.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue's foundational progress in shielding taxpayers from bank failures, perfectly aligning with their mandate to prioritize public financial sovereignty over private sector bailouts  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's advancement of cross-border crisis management mechanisms, viewing the federalization of bank issue as essential to preventing renationalization of losses during systemic collapses  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the strict application of bail-in rules under Article 27 as a critical safeguard against premature state recapitalizations, reinforcing market discipline in line with ecological-social economic principles  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's alignment with their campaign to eliminate "too big to fail" institutions, urging rapid adoption of complementary structural reform proposals to complete this legislative ecosystem  
 While welcoming the issue's liability hierarchy, GREEN_EFA emphasizes the imperative to finalize banking separation rules and EU-level issue financing to fully realize crisis prevention objectives

GUE_NGL rejects the issue as fundamentally incompatible with their demand for immediate public control over financial systems.  
GUE_NGL opposes the eight-year timeline for establishing a issue fund, condemning it as a reckless delay that leaves populations vulnerable to recurring crises.  
GUE_NGL asserts the proposal perpetuates "too big to fail" dynamics by prioritizing zombie banks over economic recovery for workers.  
GUE_NGL condemns the concentration of power in the ECB, citing its anti-democratic structure and failure to subordinate financial interests to public welfare.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address speculative mechanisms that caused Cyprus/Greek debt crises, favoring bankers over austerity-ravaged communities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the harmonization of financial regulations within the EU, based on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0280) under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), aimed at ensuring market stability and legal clarity. It emphasized adherence to the ordinary legislative procedure (Article 294 TFEU) and incorporated opinions from the European Central Bank (November 2012) and the European Economic and Social Committee (December 2012), which underscored the need for robust oversight and stakeholder input. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading position, stressing the importance of aligning national regulations to prevent fragmentation, while mandating the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It further directed the President to communicate Parliament’s stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and procedural continuity. The Committees on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Budgets, and Legal Affairs contributed to the resolution, reflecting cross-sectoral priorities in economic governance and legal coherence.

title: Global economic governance: REPORT on Global Economic Governance
background: Persistent global economic imbalances, post-2008 crisis recovery challenges, and rising influence of emerging economies prompted international efforts to strengthen financial regulation through G20 coordination and IMF governance reforms. The Parliament will discuss enhancing multilateral frameworks for global economic stability and addressing systemic risks in international monetary systems.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely supports the issue's emphasis on global implementation of financial transaction taxes, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to preventing market distortions through coordinated international frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for unified EU external economic policies, strongly approveing enhanced EU representation in the WTO and IMF as critical to advancing transatlantic regulatory coherence.  
EPP entirely supports structural reforms and fiscal consolidation measures outlined in the issue, reflecting EPP's longstanding prioritization of macro-economic stability through austerity discipline.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's governance reforms at the IMF, including merit-based leadership selection, which directly advances EPP's vision of transparent multilateral institutions.  
EPP entirely supports leveraging EU internal stability as a foundation for global economic leadership, aligning perfectly with the issue's integration of BRIC nations and climate action into trade policies.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on IMF and WTO frameworks, viewing them as enforcers of capitalist exploitation inconsistent with democratic sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the premise of systemic risk mitigation through existing financial institutions, arguing these entities perpetuate global inequalities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal for enhanced EU representation in international bodies, citing historical complicity in austerity measures and rights repression.  
GUE_NGL disputes the issue's focus on technical reforms, demanding instead a complete break from capitalist-driven economic governance models.  
GUE_NGL challenges the legitimacy of G20 monitoring mechanisms, highlighting their undemocratic nature and alignment with corporate interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about global economic imbalances, systemic financial risks, and the need for enhanced international governance to address inequalities, unsustainable growth, and environmental degradation. It emphasized correcting structural imbalances through coordinated fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, and exchange rate flexibility aligned with economic fundamentals, urging adherence to IMF and WTO rules to prevent currency manipulation. The resolution advocated reforming the IMF’s governance, including increased voting rights for emerging economies and merit-based leadership selection, and exploring Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) as a potential global reserve currency. It called for stronger EU representation in international bodies like the IMF and World Bank, unified external economic policies under the Lisbon Treaty, and enhanced transatlantic regulatory cooperation, particularly on Basel III implementation, financial transaction taxes, and commodity derivatives oversight. The Parliament highlighted the G20’s role in monitoring imbalances using indicators such as public debt, trade flows, and private savings, while critiquing its lack of legal bindingness and democratic accountability. It stressed the need for global financial regulation to address systemic risks, including stricter capital requirements for "too big to fail" institutions and standardized risk assessment models. The EU was urged to reduce energy dependency, curb imported inflation, and promote sustainable trade policies integrating BRIC nations, climate action, and ILO standards. Specific measures included combating tax evasion through automatic information exchange, addressing food price volatility via improved supply chains, and aligning trade agreements with the UN’s Millennium Development Goals. The resolution noted the US and EU’s combined 40% share of global trade and 50% of global GDP, underscoring their responsibility in fostering stable, equitable global economic frameworks.

title: Key information documents for investment products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information documents for investment products
background: The 2008 financial crisis exposed retail investor vulnerabilities and inconsistent EU financial product regulations, prompting post-crisis reforms. The European Commission’s 2012 proposal addressed fragmented disclosure rules to improve consumer understanding of investment risks. The Parliament will discuss standardizing pre-contractual information documents for retail investment products to enhance transparency and investor protection.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue's transparency measures, which align perfectly with their longstanding commitment to consumer protection and restoring trust in financial markets.  
EPP approves the KID framework as it effectively advances their priority of enabling informed retail investment decisions through coherent regulatory alignment with MiFID II and UCITS V.  
EPP proposes refining the product scope to exclude standard life insurance contracts, ensuring focus on complex structured products while maintaining safeguards for sovereign bonds and corporate debt instruments.  
EPP emphasizes enhancing cost disclosure requirements to explicitly itemize distributor-specific fees, addressing concerns about hidden charges undermining retail investor returns.  
EPP advocates streamlined risk presentation methodologies to avoid information overload, endorsing multifactorial performance scenarios over reliance on historical data alone.

ALDE entirely agrees the issue’s emphasis on standardizing key information documents to empower retail investors through transparent, comparable product disclosures.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the inclusion of life insurance products within the scope, ensuring parity in consumer comparisons across all investment-like offerings.  
ALDE strongly endorses the mandate for explicit fee transparency, prohibiting hidden costs and requiring clear quantification of charges’ impact on returns as outlined in the annex.  
ALDE applauds the adoption of their proposal for an ESA-developed online fund calculator, a tool that directly advances consumer-driven market efficiency.  
ALDE emphasizes the criticality of the complexity label mechanism, which operationalizes Union-wide criteria to flag products with inherently risky features while preserving market diversity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0352) concerning internal market regulations under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing alignment with legal frameworks and stakeholder consultations, including the European Central Bank’s December 2012 opinion and the European Economic and Social Committee’s November 2012 opinion. The resolution adopted the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A7-0368/2013), incorporating input from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. It formally endorsed Parliament’s first-reading stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and institutional coordination.

title: Long-term sustainability of public finances for a recovering economy: REPORT on the long-term sustainability of public finances for a recovering economy
background: The 2008 financial crisis prompted significant EU government stimulus spending, exacerbating pre-existing fiscal strains from ageing populations and raising concerns over long-term debt sustainability amid economic recovery. Institutional frameworks like the Stability and Growth Pact faced scrutiny post-crisis. The Parliament will discuss balancing fiscal consolidation with sustainable public finances in a post-crisis economy.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's fiscal consolidation targets and debt ceiling, aligning with their manifesto commitment to "sustainable growth through disciplined budgetary frameworks".  
EPP approves the emphasis on pension reforms and labor market modernization, echoing Karas' call for "structural reforms to protect welfare systems" through extended retirement ages.  
EPP endorses the innovation-driven growth model, matching Bendtsen's emphasis on SME competitiveness and Hökmark's demand for "productivity-driven investments in green technologies".  
EPP highlights the critical need for strengthened Stability and Growth Pact enforcement, converting Kariņš' fiscal responsibility analogy into a governance enhancement proposal.  
EPP proposes enhancing regional policy coordination with EU2020 goals, reflecting Kolarska-Bobińska's warning against "renationalization of development strategies".

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue's reliance on expenditure cuts without equitable tax reforms, contradicting their demand for fiscal coordination targeting corporate profits and capital gains.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the omission of binding green employment targets in the EU 2020 strategy, inconsistent with their manifesto's 8-million-job energy transition vision under Articles 9 and 153 TFEU.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's structural pension reforms as undermining social cohesion, failing to address the 84 million in poverty cited in Emilie Turunen's intervention.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's 20% emissions target as incompatible with green innovation urgency, highlighting Bas Eickhout's critique of subsidizing greenhouse sectors over sustainable agriculture.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the technocratic growth model neglecting cultural macro-regions, directly conflicting with François Alfonsi's call for Danube/Baltic strategies in Resolution Clause 4.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns about the long-term sustainability of public finances in the EU, exacerbated by high deficits and debt levels following the 2008 financial crisis and demographic challenges, particularly aging populations, which are projected to have a sustainability gap 5-20 times greater than the crisis's impact. It criticized insufficient pre-crisis compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), which weakened fiscal resilience, and emphasized the urgent need for structural reforms, including pension and healthcare system adjustments, raising retirement ages, and addressing declining birth rates through potential incentives and immigration. The resolution called for coordinated fiscal exit strategies starting in 2011 to reduce deficits without undermining recovery, targeting a 1% annual GDP reduction in sustainability gaps and a public debt-to-GDP ratio ceiling of 60%. It stressed the importance of sound public finances to protect welfare systems, advocated for productivity-driven investments in innovation and green technologies under the EU 2020 strategy, and highlighted the ECB's role in financial stability. The Parliament also urged improved statistical governance, better economic policy coordination, and warned against inflation risks, underscoring the link between fiscal discipline, market confidence, and sustainable growth.

title: Macro-prudential oversight of the financial system and establishment of a European Systemic Risk Board: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on Community macro prudential oversight of the financial system and establishing a European Systemic Risk Board
background: The 2008 financial crisis exposed vulnerabilities in the EU's financial system, with integrated markets and cross-border institutions operating under fragmented national supervision frameworks. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Systemic Risk Board and harmonized macro-prudential oversight mechanisms to address systemic risks and strengthen financial stability across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly endorses the issue's integration of macro-prudential oversight with the European Central Bank's institutional framework, perfectly aligning with their commitment to supranational financial stability architecture.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the cross-border crisis management provisions, emphasizing the necessity of eliminating national supervisory fragmentation to protect EU citizens' savings and pension systems.  
EPP fully supports granting the European Systemic Risk Board authority to monitor foreign bank activities in non-euro Member States, recognizing this as critical for preventing asymmetric risks in integrated markets.  
EPP endorses the issue's urgency in operationalizing supervisory intervention rights, affirming that direct EU-level action during emergencies advances their manifesto pledge for taxpayer protection.  
EPP strongly advocates maintaining the ECB's central role in risk assessment, consistent with their longstanding position that Community institutions must anchor systemic oversight mechanisms.

GUE_NGL fully opposes the issue's failure to establish binding EU-wide financial market controls, contradicting their demand for centralized regulatory authority.  
GUE_NGL rejects the fragmented supervisory architecture as incompatible with their principle of unified oversight to curb systemic risks.  
The proposal dangerously overlooks critical aspects like capital adequacy requirements, perpetuating the dominance of financial institutions over public interest.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's diluted intervention powers as irreconcilable with their manifesto commitment to "tame predatory financial capitalism."  
This framework's reliance on voluntary coordination fully condemns with GUE_NGL's insistence on legally enforceable mechanisms to prevent crises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of a legislative position at first reading based on the Treaty of Lisbon and Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aligning with the European Central Bank’s 2009 opinion and the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2010 recommendations. The resolution formalized Parliament’s stance on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0499) and urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal for further parliamentary scrutiny if substantial amendments or replacements were planned. It also mandated the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring interinstitutional coordination and transparency in the legislative process.

title: Improving access to finance for SMEs: REPORT on improving access to finance for SMEs
background: SMEs, comprising 98% of EU businesses and 67% of employment, faced constrained credit access post-2008 financial crisis due to bank lending tightening, regulatory burdens, and regional disparities in financing costs despite existing EU initiatives like the Small Business Act. The Parliament will discuss measures to enhance SME financial accessibility across diverse business models.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s prioritization of diversified funding mechanisms such as COSME and Horizon 2020, which align perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to fostering SME innovation and reducing over-reliance on traditional bank loans.  

ALDE applauds the €10 billion EIB capital increase as a critical measure to amplify SME liquidity, strongly reflecting ALDE’s advocacy for leveraging EU financial instruments to overcome post-crisis credit constraints.  

ALDE emphasizes the need to enhance awareness campaigns for EU funding programs, proposing simplified multilingual platforms to address the persistent knowledge gaps among SMEs about available support—a minor but vital enhancement to maximize existing mechanisms.  

ALDE strongly upholds the integration of mentorship initiatives like Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs, underscoring their alignment with ALDE’s focus on practical skill-building and cross-border collaboration to strengthen SME competitiveness.  

ALDE endorses the call for equitable access to international markets, urging accelerated implementation of tailored credit lines and export training programs to empower SMEs against global competition, consistent with ALDE’s free-trade principles.

GUE/NGL firmly rejects with the issue's reliance on recapitalized private banks to finance SMEs, noting these institutions prioritize speculative profits over productive investments despite public bailouts.  
GUE/NGL rejects the proposal's failure to address collapsing consumer demand as SMEs' core challenge, demanding wage increases and pension reforms instead of credit-focused measures.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's omission of public banking alternatives to redirect savings into job-creating SMEs, consistent with their anti-austerity platform.  
GUE/NGL opposes the text's implicit endorsement of fiscal consolidation policies that suppress workers' purchasing power - the root cause of SME sales declines.  
GUE/NGL condemns the report's silence on redistributive economic policies to counter austerity-driven consumption collapse in countries like Portugal.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the critical role of SMEs in the EU economy, noting they represent over 98% of businesses, provide 67% of jobs, and created 85% of new jobs between 2002–2010. It highlighted persistent challenges in SME access to finance, exacerbated by the financial crisis, with disparities in lending rates, high rejection rates in some Member States, and over-reliance on bank loans, which account for 75–90% of SME financing. The resolution urged diversified funding mechanisms, including venture capital, mezzanine finance, and EU programs like COSME and Horizon 2020, while advocating for a 20% allocation of Horizon 2020’s budget to SME innovation. It welcomed the €10 billion capital increase for the EIB to boost SME lending by €60 billion (2012–2015) and called for simplified regulations, accelerated implementation of the Late Payments Directive, and reduced administrative burdens, including a single EU-wide SME identification system. The Parliament emphasized the need for tailored financial instruments, mentorship programs, and entrepreneurship education, while stressing equitable access to public procurement and safeguards against discrimination in financing for SMEs led by disadvantaged groups. It also proposed a European Guarantee Platform to ease SME access to guarantees and urged leveraging household savings and Structural Funds to support SME growth, job creation, and regional economic cohesion.

title: Improving economic governance and stability framework in the EU, in particular in the euro zone: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on improving the economic governance and stability framework of the Union, in particular in the euro area
background: The 2008 financial crisis and 2010 eurozone sovereign debt challenges highlighted weaknesses in EU economic governance frameworks, including insufficient fiscal coordination and enforcement of stability mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss reforms to strengthen economic policy integration, fiscal discipline, and crisis prevention measures within the euro area.

stances.stance:
SD strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on synchronizing national reforms with EU objectives through the European Semester, aligning with SD's commitment to cohesive economic strategies that balance fiscal responsibility and social equity.  
SD applauds the inclusion of macroeconomic indicators like unemployment levels and public investment rates, which directly advance SD's priority of linking economic governance to real-world social outcomes.  
SD proposes enhancing the multilateral surveillance framework by explicitly mandating gender-disaggregated employment data to ensure crisis responses address structural inequalities.  
SD strongly endorses the call for a permanent European stabilization mechanism, viewing this as foundational to achieving SD's long-standing advocacy for EU-level solidarity instruments beyond ad-hoc crisis measures.  
SD approves the debt sustainability assessments but recommends amending Article 7 to require parallel reporting on Member States' social protection expenditure thresholds as buffers against austerity-driven instability.

ECR rejects the proposed multilateral surveillance framework and Excessive Debt Surveillance Procedure as reminiscent of centralized socialist planning, which undermines national economic sovereignty.  
ECR opposes the creation of a European stabilisation mechanism, warning that it entrenches moral hazard and shifts financial burdens onto taxpayers rather than market actors.  
ECR absolutely opposes harmonized budget reporting and reinforced Eurostat powers, viewing these as steps towards an EU fiscal union that erodes member state autonomy.  
ECR condemns the alignment with the Europe 2020 strategy's targets as inconsistent with their principles, arguing that top-down economic governance stifles market-driven growth.  
ECR challenges the feasibility of common EU bonds and tax policy coordination, asserting that such measures disproportionately benefit stronger economies at the expense of newer member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance EU economic governance, particularly within the euro area, by strengthening fiscal discipline, macroeconomic surveillance, and crisis management. It emphasized aligning policies with the Europe 2020 strategy’s targets for smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth, proposing a multilateral surveillance framework with a scoreboard of indicators—including real exchange rates, current accounts, unit labor costs, credit growth, and debt dynamics—to detect imbalances, trigger early warnings, and enforce corrective actions. The resolution called for stricter enforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), introducing an Excessive Debt Surveillance Procedure (EDSP) to monitor debt sustainability, contingent liabilities (e.g., pensions), and fiscal consolidation timelines, aiming to realign deficits with SGP rules by 2015. It advocated for a "European Semester" to synchronize national budgetary and reform plans (SCPs and NRPs) with EU oversight, enhanced transparency, and involvement of national parliaments. To address crises, it proposed a permanent European stabilisation mechanism (e.g., a European Monetary Fund) based on existing tools, alongside feasibility studies for common EU bonds. Other measures included tax policy coordination to combat fraud, reinforced Eurostat powers to audit national statistics, and harmonized budget reporting. The resolution urged institutional reforms, such as consolidating Commission roles, improving Euro Group accountability, and exploring Treaty changes for deeper integration, while safeguarding ECB independence and balancing fiscal discipline with investments in cohesion, innovation, and social protections.

title: Mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation
background: Following the 2011 EU Directive on administrative tax cooperation and the European Commission’s 2013 proposal, amid global efforts against tax evasion led by OECD and G20, the Parliament will discuss expanding mandatory automatic exchange of tax information to include dividends, capital gains, and financial account balances.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally sanctions the expanded automatic information exchange as a vital step to combat tax evasion, perfectly aligning with their commitment to fiscal justice and market integrity.  
EPP highlights the necessity of precise legal definitions in the directive to ensure uniform interpretation across member states, strengthening its effectiveness against tax avoidance.  
EPP acknowledges the transitional value of the availability condition to prevent disproportionate administrative burdens while maintaining full compliance with long-term transparency goals.  
EPP emphasizes the critical role of EU-level negotiations with third countries to establish global standards, reinforcing Europe’s leadership in fair taxation practices.  
EPP stresses the importance of harmonized data protection safeguards to balance transparency with fundamental privacy rights, ensuring trust in the EU’s fiscal framework.

GREEN_EFA completely disputes with the proposal's tolerance of legislative loopholes that perpetuate tax avoidance by multinational corporations.  
GREEN_EFA opposes any dilution of automatic information exchange requirements, condemning amendments that preserve opacity for corporate tax dodgers.  
 Debate content shows GREEN_EFA supporting the issue's core aims while criticizing weakening amendments. The 0 score contradicts their explicit endorsement of transparency mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0348) by approving the amended text under Article 115 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which governs harmonization measures for the internal market. It endorsed the proposal as revised, urging the Commission to adjust its initial draft in line with Parliament’s amendments under Article 293(2) of the Treaty, which requires the Council to act unanimously after consulting Parliament. The resolution emphasized procedural cooperation, instructing the Council to notify Parliament if it intends to deviate from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament if proposing substantial changes to the Commission’s original proposal. Parliament also directed its President to formally communicate its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional transparency and alignment in the legislative process.

title: Markets in financial instruments and amendment of the EMIR Regulation on OTC derivatives, central counterparties and trade repositories: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on markets in financial instruments and amending Regulation [EMIR] on OTC derivatives, central counterparties and trade repositories
background: Post-2008 financial crisis reforms revealed gaps in EU financial market oversight, particularly regarding non-transparent trading venues and insufficient derivatives regulation under EMIR. The Parliament will discuss updating MiFID and EMIR frameworks to strengthen market transparency, investor protections, and systemic risk management for OTC derivatives and trading infrastructures.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the constraints on high-frequency trading, aligning with their commitment to market stability and real economy focus, particularly in preventing speculative practices that undermine price discovery mechanisms.  
SD endorses the imposition of position limits on commodity derivatives as critical to curbing food price speculation, reflecting their developmental priorities to protect vulnerable populations from market-driven crises.  
SD approves the enhanced transparency requirements for financial instruments, seeing them as essential to consumer protection and consistent with their long-standing advocacy for eliminating opaque commission structures.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 23 to explicitly ban retroactive commission payments across all Member States, ensuring uniform investor protection against biased financial advice.   
SD applauds the expanded supervisory role of ESMA in prohibiting toxic financial products, which aligns perfectly with their 2012 manifesto commitment to systemic risk reduction and regulatory accountability.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue for maintaining derivatives markets' structural dominance, fundamentally opposing Inês Zuber's demand to abolish speculative financial instruments entirely.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal's failure to mandate political control over financial systems, contradicting their principle requiring elimination of tax havens and speculative capitalism.  
GUE_NGL condemns commodity market provisions as superficial adjustments, echoing Jürgen Klute's critique of unresolved loopholes in food speculation safeguards.  
GUE_NGL dismisses the regulatory framework for preserving high-frequency trading mechanisms despite technical restrictions, conflicting with their anti-financialization stance.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue incompatible with systemic economic transformation, aligning with Zuber's assessment that it merely inserts "miniscule spanners" in exploitative markets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0652) concerning harmonization measures under Article 114 of the TFEU, adopting amendments at first reading to strengthen regulatory coherence and address internal market objectives. It emphasized the need for the Commission to ensure alignment with parliamentary priorities, particularly in economic, developmental, and energy-related policies, as outlined in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A7-0303/2012) and supported by the opinions of the Committees on Development and Industry, Research, and Energy. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts to the original proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and democratic accountability. Additionally, it mandated the Parliament’s President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional collaboration and adherence to EU legislative procedures.

title: Markets in financial instruments and repeal of Directive 2004/39/EC: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on markets in financial instruments repealing Directive 2004/39/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council (recast)
background: The 2008 financial crisis exposed regulatory gaps in EU financial markets, prompting G20 commitments (2009) to enhance transparency and oversight, particularly for over-the-counter derivatives. The European Commission's 2011 proposal aimed to update the 2004 Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID I) amid evolving trading practices. The Parliament will discuss reforms to strengthen market transparency, investor protection, and commodity derivatives regulation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the enhanced transparency requirements for OTC financial instruments, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to investor protection and market integrity.  
EPP applauds the strict regulation of high-frequency trading through minimum order periods, effectively advancing EPP's priority of curbing speculative risks while maintaining market efficiency.  
EPP endorses the harmonized supervisory framework through ESMA, which matches their 2023 manifesto goals for cross-border financial stability and coordinated crisis response.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 16(3) to allow Member State discretion on commission-based advisory models, ensuring alignment with diverse national financial service ecosystems without opposing the transparency principle.  
EPP strongly sanctions position limits on commodity derivatives as a critical safeguard against price distortion, directly reflecting EPP's focus on linking financial markets to real economic needs.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's incremental approach to financial regulation as fundamentally inadequate to combat systemic speculation  
GUE_NGL opposes maintaining derivatives markets, demanding complete abolition rather than partial loophole closures in commodity trading  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to address tax havens, viewing this omission as enabling continued financial sector exploitation mechanisms  
GUE_NGL asserts the proposal contradicts core principles by preserving speculative infrastructure rather than establishing public control over finance  
GUE_NGL denounces "miniscule spanner" reforms that leave profit-driven market mechanisms fundamentally intact against social needs

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0656) to codify existing legislation, emphasizing that the proposal, as analyzed by the Consultative Working Party, did not introduce substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, thereby confirming it as a straightforward codification of prior acts without altering their substance. The resolution endorsed the codification process under Article 53(1) TFEU, aligning with opinions from the European Central Bank (March 2012) and the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012), and referenced committee reports (A7-0306/2012) to affirm procedural compliance. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if future amendments substantially deviate from the current text and instructed the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with the Interinstitutional Agreement on recasting legal acts (2001) and Treaty obligations.

title: Motions for resolutions - Feasibility of introducing stability bonds: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the feasibility of introducing stability bonds (2011/2959(RSP))
background: Persistent eurozone sovereign debt market strains, divergent national fiscal policies under a shared currency, and the 2011 Commission Green Paper examining joint debt instruments preceded discussions. The Parliament will discuss the feasibility of introducing stability bonds to address fiscal integration challenges within the euro area’s evolving economic governance framework.

stances.stance:
SD entirely advocates the issue’s emphasis on stability bonds as a critical mechanism to counter speculative attacks and enhance the euro’s global safe-haven status, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to collective fiscal responsibility and crisis resilience.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for binding fiscal frameworks prior to joint bond issuance, emphasizing that this approach directly advances SD’s priority of preventing moral hazard while ensuring growth-oriented economic governance.  
SD entirely advocates the linkage between stability bonds and democratic legitimacy through institutions like the European Parliament, reflecting SD’s unwavering stance on integrating fiscal coordination with transparent, accountable decision-making.  
SD strongly approves the issue’s urgency in finalizing the ESM treaty and advancing eurobills, which effectively aligns with SD’s demand for immediate crisis tools to halt contagion and stabilize sovereign debt markets.  
SD perfectly aligns with the insistence on parallel progress toward joint debt management and fiscal discipline, recognizing this dual track as essential to safeguarding both the euro’s stability and social cohesion across Member States.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s prerequisite of binding fiscal frameworks as a condition for stability bonds, completely disputeing with their stance that austerity-driven governance perpetuates economic inequality and denies vital financial tools to crisis-hit nations.  
GUE_NGL opposes the strategic focus on establishing the euro as a global reserve currency, arguing this overlooks critical aspects such as job creation and social welfare in favor of reinforcing speculative financial architectures.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s moral hazard narrative as inconsistent with their principles, asserting that conditioning joint liability on prior compliance with austerity measures entrenches systemic imbalances rather than resolving debt crises.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s retention of differentiated interest rates for member states, viewing this as a failure to address speculative attacks and a perpetuation of core-periphery economic divides.  
GUE_NGL opposes the linkage between stability bonds and the Euro Plus Pact, demanding instead the repeal of fiscal compacts that prioritize austerity over public investment and social equity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent strains in eurozone sovereign bond markets, marked by widening spreads, high volatility, and speculative attacks over two years, emphasizing the eurozone’s co-responsibility for global monetary stability as the issuer of the world’s second reserve currency. It highlighted the strategic importance of leveraging the euro’s potential as a global safe haven and developing a unified, liquid bond market comparable in size to the US Treasury market but currently lacking in liquidity and pricing efficiency. The resolution welcomed the Commission’s Green Paper on stability bonds as a starting point for debate but stressed that none of its three proposed options alone address the current debt crisis. It underscored the necessity of a binding fiscal framework, akin to the Maastricht criteria, to ensure economic governance, growth, and stability culture before joint bond issuance, while addressing moral hazard and joint liability. The Parliament noted that stability bonds could incentivize compliance with fiscal rules and enhance monetary policy transmission, contingent on deeper integration and prior reforms, including measures from the December 2011 European Council. It urged rapid proposals to tackle the crisis, such as a European redemption pact, finalizing the ESM treaty, eurobills, or joint debt management, and deemed the resolution a preliminary step ahead of a comprehensive INI report. The resolution also emphasized the eurozone’s responsibility to safeguard the currency used by over 330 million people and its global economic impact.

title: Motions for resolutions - Financial services: Lack of progress in Council and Commission's delay in the adoption of certain proposals: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on financial services: lack of progress in Council and Commission’s delay in the adoption of certain proposals
background: The European Commission proposed multiple financial services regulations between 2010-2012, including Deposit Guarantee Schemes and MiFID reforms, facing delays in Council negotiations. The 2012 European Council emphasized timely adoption, while unmet deadlines and the 2013 Cypriot banking crisis underscored urgency. The Parliament will discuss delayed financial legislation adoption impacting Banking Union completion and market stability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the urgent adoption of the Deposit Guarantee Schemes and Investor-Compensation Schemes directives, aligning perfectly with EPP’s commitment to safeguarding citizens’ savings and reinforcing investor confidence amid financial instability.  
EPP approves the issue’s emphasis on finalizing the MiFID review and Central Securities Depositories Regulation, which effectively advance EPP’s priority of regulating complex financial instruments and ensuring secure cross-border transactions.  
EPP highlights the critical need to operationalize the Single Resolution Mechanism and structural bank reforms, underscoring their longstanding advocacy for a resilient Banking Union to limit taxpayer risks.
