It also addressed transport sector disparities, advocating harmonized VAT for intra-EU travel and taxing services at the place of departure, while supporting reduced rates for public transport on social and environmental grounds. The resolution underscored the need to balance VAT efficiency with fairness, protect non-profit organizations, and align reforms with the Europe 2020 strategy, urging the Commission to propose simplified cross-border taxation rules by 2012 and consolidate anti-fraud legislation.

title: Towards a genuine Economic and Monetary Union: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on the report of the Presidents of the European Council, the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the Eurogroup "Towards a genuine Economic and Monetary Union"
background: Persistent eurozone instability following the 2008 financial crisis, sovereign debt challenges, and the 2012 European Council mandate for a roadmap on deeper integration prompted evaluation of EMU reforms. The Parliament will discuss measures to enhance economic governance and institutional frameworks for a sustainable Economic and Monetary Union.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s federal vision for social convergence and debt pooling, aligning perfectly with their commitment to solidarity-driven economic governance and rejecting austerity-driven fragmentation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the binding emphasis on Europe 2020 investment targets and own-resource funding, effectively advancing their manifesto priorities for green transition financing and structural equity.  
GREEN_EFA approves the democratic accountability measures, particularly parliamentary oversight of the Eurogroup, as a critical step toward their longstanding demand for transparent, citizen-centered EU decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening the Social Pact’s convergence mechanisms by mandating quarterly progress reviews to accelerate youth unemployment reductions in line with their intergenerational justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s urgency in addressing planetary boundaries and social exclusion, aligning with their climate emergency protocols and demand for integrated ecological-economic governance.

ECR rejects the banking union proposal as it fails to address the root cause of unmanageable public debts and enables bank recapitalization through the European Stability Mechanism, which ECR views as fiscal socialism incompatible with national sovereignty.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the mutualization of debt through a redemption fund, asserting this "demutualisation of debt without commensurate mutualisation of national sovereignty" directly contradicts fiscal discipline and the principle that states retain the right to bankruptcy.  
ECR rejects the single supervisory mechanism’s "single rule book" framework, arguing its exemptions for larger Member States perpetuate regulatory arbitrage and ignore the sovereign-bank risk feedback loop criticized in the issue’s Clause 2.  
ECR opposes the assumption of monetary union viability, citing irreconcilable labor cost disparities and lack of economic commonality in the euro area—a contradiction of the issue’s integration goals under Title IV.  
ECR entirely conflicts with the issue’s governance model, denouncing Eurogroup transparency measures as insufficient without prior democratic mandates via national referendums, as emphasized in Article 9’s oversight provisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to strengthen the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) through enhanced democratic legitimacy, deeper integration, and social cohesion, emphasizing that the EMU must serve sustainable growth, employment, and solidarity. It called for a banking union with a single supervisory mechanism to oversee credit institutions, prevent regulatory arbitrage, and manage failing banks, alongside deposit guarantees, stress-testing, and a unified prudential framework. The resolution stressed the necessity of a fiscal union with binding economic policy coordination, a redemption fund to manage debt, and increased EU budgetary capacity funded by own resources like a financial transaction tax (FTT) to address structural imbalances. It demanded greater parliamentary involvement in EU governance, including the European Parliament’s role in drafting the Annual Growth Survey, Economic Policy Guidelines, and oversight of the Eurogroup and European Stability Mechanism (ESM). Social priorities included a "Social Pact for Europe" with a youth guarantee to combat 22% youth unemployment (exceeding 50% in some states), minimum unemployment allowances, decent wages, affordable housing, and universal healthcare. The resolution highlighted the need to align national budgets with EU2020 targets, address macroeconomic imbalances, and integrate employment and social policies into economic governance, noting that EU27 unemployment had risen to 10.4% (25 million) by 2012. It urged completion of the internal market, structural reforms to boost competitiveness, and mobilization of 1% of GDP for sustainable investments, while rejecting austerity measures that undermine social protection and cohesion. Democratic accountability measures included transparency in Eurogroup decisions, regular hearings for EU officials, and enhanced roles for national parliaments in fiscal planning.

title: EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information: REPORT on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments
background: Following revelations of cross-border tax avoidance practices and prior agreements under the 2003 Savings Tax Directive, the EU and Switzerland negotiated enhanced financial account information exchange to address tax evasion. The Parliament will discuss concluding the amended protocol to align bilateral cooperation with OECD standards on automatic tax data transparency.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the agreement as fundamentally inadequate for failing to mandate retroactive application of tax information exchange, enabling past corporate tax abuses to remain concealed.  
EFDD opposes the issue's reliance on EU frameworks, which they argue institutionalize tax competition loopholes exploited by multinational corporations through jurisdictional arbitrage.  
EFDD entirely disapproves with the proposal's limited cross-border scope for information sharing, viewing this as deliberate avoidance of comprehensive transparency measures.  
EFDD highlights the agreement's exclusion of public access to records as contradictory to their anti-elitist principles demanding citizen oversight of fiscal policymaking.  
EFDD condemns the delayed implementation timeline as evidence of EU member states' collusion with corporate interests over public tax justice.

SD completely accepts the issue’s mandate for rigorous Commission monitoring of the agreement’s implementation, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to closing cross-border tax loopholes and ensuring accountability.  
SD strongly agrees the retroactive scrutiny of tax rulings beyond the proposed five-year threshold, emphasizing that comprehensive historical data exchange is critical to address systemic evasion exposed in cases like Starbucks and Fiat.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for binding EU-wide sanctions against non-compliant states, reinforcing SD’s principle that enforcement mechanisms must match the scale of tax injustice.  
SD endorses full Commission access to all exchanged tax rulings, aligning with SD’s stance that supranational oversight is indispensable to prevent member states from shielding harmful practices.  
SD applauds the issue’s emphasis on public transparency of aggregated tax ruling data, advancing SD’s priority to democratize fiscal information and empower citizen oversight.

resolution: The European Parliament raised approval of the draft Council decision and the agreement with Switzerland ensuring measures equivalent to the EU Savings Taxation Directive (2003/48/EC) to enhance taxation of interest payments, while expressing regret over unresolved shortcomings in the automatic, binding, and unrestricted exchange of tax information. It emphasized the need for robust action against tax fraud, evasion, and avoidance involving EU-based individuals and entities using third-country financial institutions. The resolution mandated the Commission to monitor the agreement’s implementation, submit a detailed assessment 18 months after its entry into force, and propose revisions if necessary. Parliament also insisted on being informed of any changes during the agreement’s finalization and reminded the Council of its obligation to re-consult Parliament if the draft decision is altered, underscoring transparency and accountability in cross-border tax cooperation.

title: Clearing obligation, reporting requirements and risk-mitigation techniques for OTC derivatives and trade repositories: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 as regards the clearing obligation, the suspension of the clearing obligation, the reporting requirements, the risk-mitigation techniques for OTC derivatives contracts not cleared by a central counterparty, the registration and supervision of trade repositories and the requirements for trade repositories
background: The 2008 financial crisis prompted the EU to adopt EMIR (2012) regulating over-the-counter derivatives, aligning with G20 commitments to enhance transparency and mitigate systemic risk. Subsequent evaluations identified operational complexities and disproportionate burdens for smaller entities. The Parliament will discuss amendments to EMIR addressing clearing obligations, reporting frameworks, and risk-mitigation requirements for derivatives markets.

stances.stance:
EFDD fundamentally rejects the issue’s expansion of OTC derivatives oversight as dangerously inadequate to prevent systemic risks like Italy’s €25 billion securitization loophole, which mirrors pre-2008 crisis practices.  
EFDD opposes Article 76a’s mutual data access mandate as bureaucratic overreach that drowns regulators in unactionable data while failing to address debt contagion mechanisms exemplified by Italian state-guaranteed CDOs.  
The proposal contradicts EFDD’s anti-centralization principles by empowering ESMA under Article 67(1) to impose urgent decisions without meaningful democratic checks, exacerbating EU technocratic overreach.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s Article 63 margin adjustments as superficial tinkering that ignores root causes of financial instability, notably the Target2 liabilities inflating Italy’s effective debt to 150% of GDP.  
 While supporting reduced reporting burdens, EFDD argues the entire framework remains a “financial dog’s dinner” of fragmented rules under Article 114 TFEU that cannot resolve currency union flaws driving sovereign-bank crises.

ECR fully accepts the streamlined EMIR provisions that eliminate disproportionate costs while safeguarding financial stability, aligning perfectly with their commitment to regulatory efficiency.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the temporary clearing obligation exemption for pension systems, ensuring both large and small programs avoid destabilizing operational burdens.  
ECR applauds the issue’s protection of small financial counterparties from €1.5 billion in avoidable costs, advancing their priority of proportionate regulation.  
ECR strongly sanctions the enhanced transparency framework, which strengthens oversight without imposing redundant reporting requirements.  
ECR commends the issue’s balance between risk mitigation and market accessibility, reflecting their principles of pragmatic financial governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised amendments to EU financial regulations to enhance market stability and transparency, focusing on over-the-counter derivatives, central counterparties, and trade repositories. Key changes include suspending clearing obligations under Article 6b in non-resolution scenarios to mitigate systemic risks, deleting redundant provisions such as Article 1(5)(a) and Article 62(5), and introducing Article 76a to mandate mutual direct data access between trade repositories to improve oversight. The resolution amended Article 67(1) to empower ESMA to adopt urgent interim decisions without prior consultation in cases of imminent financial system damage, while ensuring post-decision hearings. It revised Article 63 to adjust margin requirements for non-centrally cleared derivatives and updated Article 89 to strengthen reporting obligations for counterparties. Additional amendments included inserting new paragraphs in Articles 38 and 39 to clarify supervisory measures, modifying Article 72(2) on penalties for regulatory breaches, and updating Annex I to align with technical standards. The resolution emphasized harmonizing rules under Article 114 TFEU to prevent market fragmentation and ensure consistent application across member states.

title: Collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank: REPORT on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 2533/98 concerning the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank
background: The European Central Bank’s expanded supervisory role under the Banking Union, following the establishment of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, necessitated updated frameworks for data collection to align with its mandate. The Parliament will discuss proposed amendments to ECB statistical reporting rules to reflect its enhanced financial oversight responsibilities.

stances.stance:
ALDE totally accepts the ECB's enhanced supervisory role as critical to restoring international confidence in Europe's banking sector  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on directing penalty funds to the Bank Resolution Fund under the "polluter pays" principle  
ALDE strongly advocates mandatory publication of finalized sanction decisions to prevent pre-crisis malpractice recurrence  
ALDE applauds the streamlined information requirements as effectively advancing systemic risk prevention priorities  
ALDE recognizes the urgency provisions for investigations as fully consistent with their financial stability agenda

GUE_NGL absolutely challenges the ECB's expansion into economic policy domains, directly conflicting with their rejection of undemocratic financial centralization.  
GUE_NGL rejects the ECB's toxic asset purchases as institutionalizing systemic risk, contradicting their commitment to public banking safeguards.  
GUE_NGL condemns the merger of monetary policy and banking supervision as anti-democratic consolidation of power, opposing all issue provisions enabling this structure.  
GUE_NGL denounces ECB-imposed structural reforms in social sectors as neoliberal overreach irreconcilable with their defense of public welfare systems.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's failure to address democratic accountability gaps, highlighting its incompatibility with citizen-led economic governance principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the European Central Bank’s amended draft recommendation (11200/2014 – ECB/2014/13), grounded in Article 129(4) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Articles 5.4 and 41 of the Statute of the European System of Central Banks and the ECB. It emphasized adherence to the 2013 Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation between the European Statistical System and the European System of Central Banks. The resolution instructed the Council to notify Parliament if it intends to deviate from the approved text and to re-consult Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the ECB’s draft. Parliament further directed its President to communicate its position to the Council, the ECB, and the Commission, ensuring alignment with institutional procedures and statutory obligations.

title: Banking Union - Annual Report 2016: REPORT on Banking Union - Annual Report 2016
background: The European Banking Union, established post-2012 financial crisis to mitigate bank-sovereign risk, included the Single Supervisory Mechanism and Single Resolution Mechanism. Persistent challenges included high non-performing loans in Eurozone states, sovereign debt exposure risks, and incomplete elements like a common deposit insurance scheme. The Parliament will discuss the Banking Union's implementation progress and remaining structural reforms.

stances.stance:
SD absolutely endorses the issue's urgent call for a European Deposit Insurance Scheme, perfectly aligning with SD's longstanding commitment to break the bank-sovereign risk nexus and protect citizen deposits.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on addressing €1 trillion in NPLs through asset management companies, reinforcing SD's priority to stabilize banking sectors via coordinated EU-wide solutions.  
SD absolutely endorses harmonizing sovereign debt prudential treatment as critical to eliminating "home bias," advancing SD's vision of integrated financial risk management across member states.  
SD perfectly supports strengthening the Single Supervisory Mechanism's accountability frameworks, recognizing this as essential for maintaining public trust in EU banking oversight institutions.  
SD absolutely endorses accelerated completion of the Banking Union's third pillar, viewing the fiscal backstop proposal as vital to fulfilling SD's financial stability objectives for the eurozone economy.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s claims of preventing taxpayer-funded bailouts, citing Italy’s banking crisis as proof that existing rules perpetuate public liability for private bank failures.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the reliance on bail-in mechanisms, which fail to protect citizens from bearing crisis costs, as evidenced by the ECB’s opaque handling of Monte dei Paschi’s capital shortfall.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address austerity policies exacerbating non-performing loans, directly conflicting with their demand for ending Troika-style fiscal constraints.  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of bank structural reforms separating commercial and investment banking, a critical measure to resolve systemic “too-big-to-fail” risks.  
GUE_NGL asserts the proposal overlooks ECB accountability flaws, maintaining mechanisms that shift banking sector costs onto ordinary families despite claims of “fair burden-sharing.”

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the incomplete Banking Union, emphasizing the urgent need for a fiscal backstop and a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) to break the bank-sovereign risk nexus and ensure financial stability. It highlighted the €1,014 billion in non-performing loans (NPLs) held by euro area banks as of April 2016, urging coordinated EU and national measures, including asset management companies, improved insolvency frameworks, and reduced dividend payouts to strengthen bank capital. The resolution stressed risks from sovereign debt exposure and "home bias" in government bond holdings, calling for harmonized prudential treatment aligned with international standards. It advocated reducing variability in risk-weighted asset calculations, enhancing transparency in supervisory practices, and finalizing Basel III reforms while safeguarding EU banking models. The Parliament supported strengthening the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) by addressing staffing gaps, improving IT systems, and ensuring accountability, while cautioning against conflicts of interest in the ECB’s dual roles. It endorsed measures to tackle "too-big-to-fail" institutions through bail-in mechanisms, Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity (TLAC), and harmonized resolution frameworks, alongside addressing shadow banking risks and cybersecurity threats. The resolution called for completing the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM) with a robust fiscal backstop, harmonizing deposit guarantee schemes, and ensuring fair burden-sharing. It emphasized proportionality in regulation, improved stress testing methodologies, and enhanced macroprudential oversight to mitigate systemic risks, while urging alignment of international standards with EU-specific needs to maintain competitiveness and financial stability.

title: Banking Union - Annual Report 2017: REPORT on Banking Union – Annual Report 2017
background: Persistent challenges in eurozone banking stability, including divergent non-performing loan levels, ECB assessments of failing banks, and incomplete Banking Union structures, alongside ongoing reforms like the Single Supervisory Mechanism and Council action plans, shaped 2017 discussions. The Parliament will discuss Banking Union implementation, financial risk management, and institutional coordination to strengthen regulatory frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the completion of the Banking Union through accelerated implementation of EDIS and a permanent fiscal backstop for the SRF, aligning with their commitment to financial stability and crisis resilience.  
EPP endorses harmonized insolvency frameworks and enhanced secondary NPL markets, emphasizing measurable progress on both stock and flow reductions to unlock SME lending.  
EPP proposes strengthening cross-border supervisory mechanisms to address blind spots in anti-money laundering oversight, ensuring EU-level detection parity with third-country systems.  
EPP advocates maintaining proportionality in capital requirements and issue planning to preserve diverse banking models critical for regional economies.  
EPP urges concrete risk-reduction milestones on sovereign exposures and NPL issue before advancing EDIS to full risk-sharing, ensuring balanced progress.

ENF rejects the issue's prioritization of a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) before systemic risk reduction, directly conflicting with their principle that sovereign debt exposure must be resolved prior to risk-sharing.  
ENF opposes the issue’s claims of effective supervision, citing the ABLV Bank failure as evidence of ECB oversight deficiencies inconsistent with proposed "enhanced supervision" measures in Article 12.  
ENF highlights the issue’s failure to address critical gaps in stress-test methodologies, particularly the ABLV case where U.S. authorities exposed flaws the ECB missed, undermining Paragraph 9’s stress-test harmonization goals.  
ENF fundamentally disputes the issue’s assumption of operational readiness for crisis management, noting that reliance on non-EU authorities to detect systemic risks contradicts Clause 21’s "improved ECB-SRB cooperation" framework.  
ENF condemns the issue’s silence on preemptive sovereign-bank nexus reforms, which ENF views as a prerequisite for any deposit insurance system per their risk-reduction-first doctrine.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities to strengthen the Banking Union, emphasizing the need to address non-performing loans (NPLs), which totaled €1 trillion with a weighted average NPL ratio of 4.47% as of mid-2017. It highlighted risks from sovereign debt exposure, derivatives (€453 trillion notional value), and shadow banking, urging harmonized insolvency frameworks, improved secondary markets for NPLs, and statutory prudential backstops. The resolution stressed completing the Banking Union through a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), a fiscal backstop for the Single Resolution Fund (SRF), and breaking the sovereign-bank nexus. It called for enhanced supervision, including consistent stress-test methodologies, streamlined reporting, and proportionality for smaller banks, while addressing internal model variability and cybersecurity risks. Parliament welcomed progress in resolution mechanisms, citing cases like Banco Popular Español and Italian banks, but urged transparency in resolution decisions, improved ECB-SRB cooperation, and alignment of state aid rules with the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD). It supported implementing Basel III with EU-specific adjustments, Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity (TLAC) standards, and harmonizing deposit guarantee schemes. Concerns over Brexit’s impact on financial stability and preparations for EU-UK supervisory cooperation were noted, alongside calls to regulate FinTechs proportionately and monitor systemic risks from complex banking structures. The resolution reiterated the need to finalize crisis management reforms, accelerate NPL reductions, and ensure operational resolution plans with credible MREL targets, while advocating for a review of implicit subsidies and state aid in the banking sector.

title: Banking Union - Annual report 2015: REPORT on the Banking Union – Annual Report 2015
background: The European Banking Union, established post-2008 crisis to enhance financial stability, introduced the Single Supervisory Mechanism (2014) and Single Resolution Mechanism (2015). Challenges included divergent national banking practices, non-performing loans, sovereign exposure risks, and incomplete deposit insurance harmonization. The Parliament will discuss the Banking Union's operational effectiveness, regulatory coherence, and steps toward completing its third pillar.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the Banking Union’s foundational role in shielding taxpayers through creditor liability mechanisms, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable financial market discipline.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s prioritization of systemic risk monitoring and liquidity stress testing, effectively advancing their long-standing advocacy for macro-prudential stability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for vigilance over shadow banking activities, matching their manifesto pledge to close regulatory gaps across financial sectors.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly tackling regulatory arbitrage between banks and insurers while ensuring capital adequacy standards remain robust against dilution pressures.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need to maintain transparency in supervisory outcomes, particularly SREP disclosures, to uphold public accountability as outlined in their governance principles.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue as fundamentally incompatible with their demand for public control of banking systems and taxpayer protection from financial sector risks.  
GUE/NGL opposes the Banking Union framework for failing to address "too big to fail" concentration, evidenced by Deutsche Bank’s €60 trillion derivatives exposure exceeding German GDP twentyfold.  
GUE/NGL condemns the report’s silence on ECB supervisory failures in Greece’s 2015 bank closures and Portugal’s Banif collapse despite SSM oversight being operational.  
GUE/NGL denounces the SRM’s taxpayer-funded loopholes, citing Ireland’s ongoing €31 billion bank debt destruction as proof of unresolved bailout mechanisms.  
GUE/NGL highlights structural conflicts like Draghi’s G30 membership with bank CEOs as emblematic of the Banking Union’s regulatory capture by financial elites.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of completing the Banking Union (BU) as a cornerstone of economic and monetary union, emphasizing its three pillars: the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Single Resolution Mechanism (SRM), and a unified deposit guarantee framework. It acknowledged the SSM’s operational success since 2014 in enhancing supervisory quality and financial stability but called for reduced administrative burdens, improved proportionality in reporting (notably for smaller banks via AnaCredit thresholds), and better integration of macro-prudential policies, including liquidity stress testing and systemic risk monitoring. The resolution highlighted challenges such as non-performing loans (urging asset management solutions), insufficient credit growth, and the need to harmonize supervisory practices by closing 35 national regulatory discrepancies. It stressed the SRM’s role in resolving failing banks, advocating swift adoption of a minimum 8% MREL requirement, bridge financing for the Single Resolution Fund (SRF), and stronger cooperation between the SRB and ECB. On deposit guarantees, Parliament welcomed the proposed European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) but emphasized preconditioning it on risk reduction and BRRD implementation. Key numerical references included Greek banks’ recapitalization needs (€4.4–14.4 billion under stress tests) and the ECB’s comprehensive assessment of 2013–2014. The resolution also urged addressing sovereign exposure risks, enhancing transparency in supervisory decisions (e.g., SREP outcomes), and ensuring accountability through improved audit mechanisms and ECB engagement with Parliament. It called for global regulatory consistency, vigilance over shadow banking, and safeguarding diverse banking models while avoiding regulatory arbitrage.

title: Banking Union - Annual report 2018: REPORT on Banking Union – annual report 2018
background: Persistent challenges in the EU Banking Union framework included high non-performing loans, anti-money laundering deficiencies, and shadow banking risks. Key 2018 developments involved ECB crisis management assessments, EBA stress tests, and sovereign exposure proposals. The Parliament will discuss Banking Union progress, financial stability measures, risk reduction strategies, and regulatory harmonization efforts.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the urgent finalization of the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) and fiscal backstop, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to completing the Banking Union's risk-sharing architecture.  
SD strongly endorses enhanced anti-money laundering oversight through centralized EBA powers, effectively advancing SD's priority of creating a unified EU financial integrity framework.  
SD strongly sanctions proportional Basel III implementation to protect diverse banking models, reflecting SD's principle of ensuring equitable access to credit for SMEs and regional economies.  
SD strongly advocates for rigorous monitoring and regulation of shadow banking activities, consistent with SD's focus on mitigating systemic risks in non-traditional financial sectors.  
SD proposes streamlining cross-border supervisory coordination through standardized reporting templates to improve issue efficiency while fully maintaining integrated oversight objectives.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's emphasis on completing the Banking Union, fundamentally condemning with their stance that centralized financial frameworks perpetuate systemic risks and prioritize megabanks over public control.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposed fiscal backstop for the Single Resolution Fund, condemning it as a mechanism to funnel public funds into private banks, directly contradicting their demand for democratic oversight of financial institutions.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects such as the ECB’s role in enabling predatory asset stripping, which GUE_NGL highlights as exacerbating housing insecurity and consumer vulnerability instead of protecting them.  
GUE_NGL denounces the issue’s endorsement of Basel III adjustments, arguing that elevated leverage ratios and unchecked mergers create oligopolistic structures inconsistent with their call for decentralized, community-serving banking.  
The proposal fails to address GUE_NGL’s core critique that the ESM reforms institutionalize state aid to banks, reinforcing "too-big-to-fail" dynamics rather than dismantling them through public ownership models.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of completing the Banking Union, emphasizing the need for a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) and a fiscal backstop for the Single Resolution Fund to enhance financial stability and risk reduction. It highlighted progress in reducing non-performing loans (NPLs) but expressed concern over persistently high NPL levels in some Member States, urging improved insolvency frameworks and supervisory coordination. The resolution stressed the urgency of strengthening anti-money laundering (AML) oversight, endorsing enhanced powers for the European Banking Authority (EBA) and a unified EU approach to prudential and AML supervision. It called for tailored implementation of Basel III standards to reflect the EU’s diverse banking models, proportionality for smaller banks, and vigilance against sovereign debt concentration risks. Concerns were raised about shadow banking (40% of the EU financial system in 2017), FinTech’s regulatory gaps, and the ECB’s dual role as monetary and supervisory authority, advocating clearer separation. The Parliament welcomed the Euro Summit’s agreement to reform the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) as the Single Resolution Fund’s backstop and urged harmonizing insolvency rules and crisis management tools. It reiterated the need to limit state aid, address "too-big-to-fail" risks, and ensure transparency in bank resolution processes, while supporting innovation in financial markets alongside robust consumer protection and cyber resilience measures.

title: Bringing transparency, coordination and convergence to corporate tax policies: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on bringing transparency, coordination and convergence to Corporate Tax policies in the Union
background: The 2014 LuxLeaks disclosures revealed widespread use of confidential tax rulings enabling multinational corporations to minimize tax liabilities through profit shifting, while OECD initiatives addressed global tax base erosion. The Parliament will discuss improving transparency, coordination, and convergence in EU corporate tax policies to address aggressive tax planning and cross-border tax base erosion.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the proposal for EU fiscal integration, declaring it incompatible with national sovereignty over taxation, directly opposing Articles 12-14 on harmonized corporate tax bases.  
ENF totally conflicts with the issue’s reliance on EU institutions led by figures implicated in LuxLeaks, dismissing its credibility to address systemic tax avoidance.  
ENF opposes the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) framework, advocating instead for unilateral national tax rate reductions to eliminate "fiscal hells" driving profit shifting.  
ENF criticizes the issue’s failure to impose binding penalties on tax advisory firms facilitating profit shifting, undermining its anti-avoidance measures in Article 7.  
ENF rejects the "Fair Tax Payer" label and spillover analyses as bureaucratic overreach, asserting these mechanisms infringe on member states’ regulatory autonomy.

GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts the issue's binding public country-by-country reporting requirements, perfectly aligning with their decade-long campaign for corporate tax transparency across all jurisdictions.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with leveraging reclaimed tax revenues to establish permanent whistleblower protection programs, recognizing these actors as vital defenders of fiscal justice.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts the mandatory spillover analysis framework as critical infrastructure to prevent national tax policies from undermining collective EU financial stability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue's integration of OECD BEPS standards with EU-controlled enforcement mechanisms, advancing their vision of supranational tax governance reform.  
GREEN_EFA highlights that the Fair Tax Payer label system directly operationalizes their principle of market rewards for ethical corporate citizenship.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over systemic corporate tax avoidance revealed by the LuxLeaks scandal, where 340 multinational companies (MNCs) secured 548 secret tax rulings in Luxembourg (2002–2010), enabling effective tax rates below 1% on shifted profits, undermining EU public finances and distorting competition. It highlighted the broader EU-wide prevalence of aggressive tax planning, costing €50–70 billion annually in lost revenues (potentially €160–190 billion including inefficiencies), disproportionately harming SMEs and public services. The resolution urged coordinated EU action to implement OECD/G20 BEPS measures as a minimum standard, enhance transparency through public reporting of tax rulings, and establish a harmonized corporate tax base (CCCTB) to prevent profit shifting. It called for legislative proposals by June 2016, including a public EU-wide register of beneficial ownership, mandatory spillover analyses for national tax measures, stricter anti-avoidance rules (e.g., controlled foreign company rules), and a "Fair Tax Payer" label for compliant companies. Additional measures included countering tax havens via trade and funding restrictions, harmonizing definitions of economic substance and permanent establishments, protecting whistleblowers, and improving dispute resolution mechanisms. The Parliament emphasized taxing profits where generated, closing loopholes in digital taxation, and ensuring policy coherence to safeguard developing countries from harmful spillovers. It stressed the need for EU-level coordination to eliminate harmful tax competition, reduce administrative burdens, and align corporate taxation with principles of fairness, transparency, and economic integration.

title: Building a Capital markets union: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Building a Capital Markets Union
background: Following the 2008 financial crisis, EU capital markets remained fragmented with heavy reliance on bank financing, limiting SME access to funding and cross-border investment. The European Commission's 2015 Green Paper highlighted structural inefficiencies and proposed integrating markets to diversify financing. The Parliament will discuss establishing a Capital Markets Union to deepen market integration and expand non-bank funding channels.

stances.stance:
ALDE entirely upholds the issue's emphasis on diversifying funding mechanisms, perfectly aligning with ALDE's longstanding commitment to completing single market integration through regulatory coherence and cross-border capital mobility.  

ALDE perfectly aligns with the call to enhance retail investor participation, proposing the strengthening of pan-European private pension frameworks to amplify long-term capital formation while maintaining strict investor safeguards.  

The issue effectively advances ALDE's priority of eliminating national gold-plating practices, which aligns with our 2023 manifesto pledge to eradicate regulatory fragmentation through ESMA's enhanced supervisory convergence mandate.  

ALDE fully supports the focus on scaling mid-cap enterprises and IPO ecosystems, recognizing this as critical to retaining European corporate sovereignty and matching ALDE's advocacy for multi-tiered capital market accessibility.  

This initiative perfectly aligns with ALDE's vision for digital finance integration, urging accelerated adoption of blockchain-based settlement systems to complement the issue's securitization revitalization goals.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the Capital Markets Union as it exacerbates financial speculation while neglecting austerity's role in stifling economic demand  
GUE_NGL rejects market-based financing mechanisms for SMEs, demanding instead public banking systems to directly address credit shortages through state intervention  
This proposal fundamentally rejects with GUE_NGL's position that wage stagnation and social spending cuts—not capital market fragmentation—are root causes of underinvestment  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of public responsibility by prioritizing private securitization products over democratic control of economic resources  
GUE_NGL condemns the CMU framework as dangerously consistent with the financialization policies that caused the 2008 crisis, rather than breaking from failed neoliberal models

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to establish a Capital Markets Union (CMU) to diversify funding sources, reduce reliance on bank financing, and address fragmentation in EU capital markets to stimulate investment, particularly for SMEs and long-term projects. It highlighted that EU capital markets lag behind the U.S., with EU mutual funds, pension funds, equity markets, corporate bonds, and securitization at 50%, 35%, 60%, 35%, and 20% of U.S. levels respectively, despite higher EU savings (20% of GDP vs. 17% in the U.S.). The resolution emphasized simplifying regulations to enhance cross-border capital flows, promote securitization, private placements, venture capital, and digital finance, while ensuring investor protection and addressing tax biases favoring debt over equity. It called for harmonizing insolvency frameworks, improving financial education, and leveraging initiatives like ELTIFs and UCITS to mobilize institutional investors. The Parliament stressed the importance of regulatory coherence, proportionality for SMEs, and stronger supervision through ESMA, while cautioning against replicating non-EU models and urging completion of CMU components by 2018. It also underscored the need to mitigate systemic risks, avoid excessive leverage, and align the CMU with digital single market and investment plan agendas.

title: Access to anti-money-laundering information by tax authorities: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards access to anti-money-laundering information by tax authorities
background: Recurrent financial scandals like Panama Papers and cross-border money laundering schemes revealed systemic gaps in interagency information sharing under existing EU anti-money laundering frameworks. The Parliament will discuss expanding tax authorities' access to financial intelligence to strengthen transnational cooperation against tax evasion and illicit fund flows.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly agrees the issue’s mandate for tax authorities’ access to AML data, perfectly aligning with their manifesto pledge to eradicate fiscal opacity and safeguard EU welfare systems through supranational cooperation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the automatic exchange of beneficial ownership information across Member States, recognizing this as indispensable for dismantling offshore tax evasion networks exposed in the Panama Papers.  
EPP emphasizes that the centralized EU register of ultimate company owners must be paired with binding sanctions against tax havens, reflecting their unyielding stance against “race-to-the-bottom” corporate tax practices.  
EPP applauds the issue’s procedural safeguards requiring Council reconsultation of Parliament, reinforcing their institutional commitment to Article 13 TEU principles of democratic accountability.  
EPP urges the Commission to champion global AML-tax transparency alliances, particularly with post-Brexit UK and U.S. administrations, to counter regressive unilateralism threatening international tax fairness.

ECR fully rejects the proposal for failing to mandate EU-wide centralized ownership registries, allowing offshore trusts to perpetuate financial opacity.  
ECR rejects the issue’s narrow EU focus, demanding global accountability mechanisms to prevent tax haven exploitation through third-country intermediaries.  
ECR criticizes the directive’s reliance on fiscal repression without addressing excessive tax complexity, arguing this disproportionately burdens compliant businesses.  
ECR opposes the inadequate measures against profit shifting, insisting on binding rules to tax corporate profits where economic activity occurs.  
 Despite isolated acknowledgments of transparency aims, ECR’s collective position emphasizes structural deficiencies overriding partial alignment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0452) by approving the amended text, urging the Commission to revise its proposal under Article 293(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to align with Parliament’s amendments. It emphasized procedural accountability by demanding the Council notify Parliament if it diverges from the approved text and reconsult Parliament for any substantial changes to the proposal. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional transparency and adherence to legislative processes under Articles 113 and 115 TFEU.

title: Action plan on retail financial services: REPORT on the Action Plan on Retail Financial Services
background: Existing EU legislation on retail financial services, persistent market fragmentation, high cross-border transaction costs, and challenges in digital innovation prompted multiple Commission Green Papers (2007-2017) and regulatory actions addressing consumer protection, payment systems, and FinTech. The Parliament will discuss advancing single market integration for retail financial services through regulatory harmonization and consumer-focused innovation.

stances.stance:
EPP fully accepts the extension of cross-border payment fee regulations to non-euro transactions, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eliminating market fragmentation and protecting consumers from disproportionate costs.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on harmonizing dynamic currency conversion rules, recognizing this as critical for ensuring transparent pricing in pan-European financial services.  
EPP strongly promotes the removal of residency-based barriers to financial product access, which directly advances their vision of a truly borderless EU retail banking market.  
EPP applauds the integration of eIDAS-based digital identification systems, seeing this as foundational for secure and efficient cross-border FinTech innovation.  
EPP fully accepts maintaining physical banking infrastructure alongside digital advancements, ensuring financial inclusion for non-digital populations while modernizing services.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue as fundamentally inadequate in addressing systemic risks posed by speculative financial products that prioritize bank profits over citizen savings protection.  
GUE_NGL opposes the reliance on transparency measures alone, arguing this fails to prohibit complex structured products like those responsible for the BES scandal in Portugal.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's contradiction with anti-austerity principles by permitting continued marketization of savings through FinTech frameworks favoring capital mobility over stability.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to mandate EU-wide bans on dynamic currency conversion abuses and residency-based financial discrimination as outlined in Articles 4-6.  
GUE_NGL asserts the proposal overlooks critical public banking alternatives, cementing private sector dominance inconsistent with their demand for democratized finance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the fragmented and underdeveloped EU retail financial services market, emphasizing the need for urgent action to enhance cross-border competition, innovation, and consumer protection. It highlighted barriers such as high fees for non-euro transactions, lack of transparency in dynamic currency conversion, and restrictive practices like residency requirements for accessing financial products. The resolution called for amendments to Regulation (EC) No 924/2009 to reduce cross-border payment fees, harmonized creditworthiness assessments to mitigate over-indebtedness, and reforms to the Motor Insurance Directive to ensure cross-border portability of no-claims bonuses. It stressed the potential of FinTech (noting Europe’s 2016 FinTech funding of USD 2.2 billion compared to USD 12.8 billion in the US and USD 8.6 billion in China) to drive competition and efficiency, urging a regulatory framework ensuring "same service, same risk, same rules" while addressing cybersecurity risks. The Parliament advocated for improved consumer transparency through quality comparison tools, streamlined disclosure requirements, and enhanced financial literacy. It supported digitalization via eIDAS Regulation for cross-border e-identification but stressed the need to maintain high street banks for vulnerable groups. The resolution urged leveraging the Capital Markets Union to promote sustainable investments, including ESG criteria and an EU savings account for ecological transition, and called for empowering EU supervisory authorities (EBA, ESMA, EIOPA) with adequate resources to enforce consumer protection and market integrity.

title: Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive on a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB)
background: In 2016, the European Commission proposed a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) directive under Article 115 TFEU, addressing fragmented national systems enabling corporate tax competition, profit shifting by multinationals, and challenges in taxing digital economy activities. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing corporate tax rules to prevent avoidance and ensure equitable cross-border taxation.

stances.stance:
ENF entirely disapproves the elimination of the 750 million revenue threshold, asserting it disproportionately impacts SMEs and contradicts subsidiarity.  
ENF rejects any federalization of tax revenues, declaring fiscal sovereignty must remain with member states as a non-negotiable principle.  
ENF condemns the Parliament's amendments restricting loss carryforwards and R&D credits, arguing they sabotage European competitiveness against global digital giants.  
ENF highlights the proposal's failure to curb tax haven practices by certain EU member states enabling American tech multinationals' fiscal vampirism.  
ENF opposes linking corporate tax harmonization to EU budget financing mechanisms, denouncing it as an existential threat to national fiscal autonomy.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the CCCTB proposal as a transformative tool to combat corporate tax evasion, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to fiscal justice and multinational accountability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on taxing digital giants like Amazon and Google where they generate value, effectively advancing their priority of closing cross-border profit-shifting loopholes.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the harmonized tax base as critical to recovering fiscal sovereignty, matching their manifesto goals to eliminate destructive tax competition between member states.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the Inditex Zara case as concrete evidence of the proposal’s urgency, urging swift implementation to prevent profit manipulation tactics exposed in their “Tax Shopping” study.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing decision-making efficiency by amending procedural provisions to activate Article 116 for qualified majority voting, ensuring prolonged national vetoes cannot block progress.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Commission’s 2016 legislative proposal (COM(2016)0683), referencing Article 115 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union as its legal basis, and noted objections from eight national parliaments (Denmark, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Sweden) asserting non-compliance with subsidiarity principles. The Parliament approved the Commission’s proposal as amended, urging the Commission to revise its draft accordingly under Article 293(2) and called on the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text or to re-consult Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It emphasized procedural accountability by instructing its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, while focusing on aligning the proposal with legislative goals and addressing subsidiarity concerns raised by member states.

title: Common Corporate Tax Base: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive on a Common Corporate Tax Base
background: The European Commission’s 2016 proposal for a Common Corporate Tax Base addressed divergent national tax rules enabling profit shifting and tax avoidance, particularly by digital multinationals, amid declining corporate tax rates post-2008 crisis and OECD efforts on global tax reform. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing corporate tax rules to prevent avoidance and ensure fair competition within the EU.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the establishment of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (BICCIS) as a transformative step to combat profit-shifting by multinationals, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal justice and closing loopholes exploited by digital giants like Google and Amazon.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the directive’s focus on taxing multinationals as single entities within the EU, ensuring taxation reflects real economic activity, which directly advances their manifesto priority of equitable tax systems.  
GREEN_EFA endorses harmonizing taxable base rules to eliminate fiscal dumping, reclaiming fiscal sovereignty for member states to enforce fair contributions from corporations, consistent with their advocacy for EU-level solidarity against tax avoidance.  
GREEN_EFA proposes leveraging Article 116 TFEU to adopt the directive via qualified majority voting, enhancing procedural efficiency to overcome years of national government obstruction while maintaining alignment with the issue’s core objectives.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the urgency of this reform by referencing cases like Inditex Zara’s tax avoidance, underscoring how the issue operationalizes their long-standing demand to replace profit-shifting with transparency and accountability.

ECR rejects the proposal as a fundamental breach of subsidiarity, conflicting with their core principle that taxation must remain a national competence under EU treaties.  
ECR opposes the harmonized tax base for enabling corporate profit shifts to large economies like Germany, directly contradicting their advocacy for small states’ competitive fiscal autonomy.  
ECR highlights the issue’s failure to safeguard unanimous tax voting rights, which would strip Ireland’s veto and expose its 12.5% corporate rate to EU coercion.  
ECR condemns the initiative’s disregard for tax competition benefits, inconsistent with their stance that intra-EU rivalry drives innovation and public spending efficiency.  
ECR underscores the proposal’s alignment with Macron’s 33% tax floor agenda, opposing this centralized "tax trespass" against low-rate economies like Malta and Luxembourg.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Commission proposal (COM(2016)0685) aimed at harmonizing national laws under Article 115 TFEU, while noting subsidiarity concerns from eight national parliaments (Denmark, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Sweden), which argued the initiative exceeded EU competence. The resolution endorsed the amended text, instructing the Commission to revise its proposal accordingly under Article 293(2) TFEU, and demanded the Council notify Parliament if deviating from the approved text or consult Parliament again for substantial amendments. It further mandated forwarding its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural accountability and alignment with legislative frameworks.

title: Common system of a digital services tax on revenues resulting from the provision of certain digital services: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive on the common system of a digital services tax on revenues resulting from the provision of certain digital services
background: Growing disparities in effective tax rates between traditional businesses and multinational digital firms, alongside international efforts to update tax frameworks under OECD guidance, prompted the European Commission to propose a harmonized EU approach. The Parliament will discuss establishing a common system for taxing digital services revenues to address tax base erosion and ensure equitable contributions.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the increased 5% DST rate and expanded scope to digital content/e-commerce, aligning perfectly with their commitment to closing digital tax loopholes exploited by multinationals.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 3 to explicitly list all covered entities, ensuring Amazon and Apple cannot evade obligations through current definitional gaps.  
GREEN_EFA approves the sunset clause but urges accelerating CCCTB adoption timelines to prevent prolonged reliance on interim DST measures.  
GREEN_EFA advocates invoking Article 116 TFEU immediately to bypass unanimity barriers, enhancing the issue's enforcement mechanisms against fiscal free-riding states.  
GREEN_EFA recommends clarifying audit requirements to mandate cross-border data-sharing between national tax authorities, addressing profit-shifting risks in user-generated revenue models.

ECR rejects the DST rate increase to 5% as completely opposeing with their principles of minimal bureaucratic taxation, arguing the "unfairness" premise remains unproven and overlooks existing shareholder-level taxation through income taxes.  
ECR opposes the expanded DST scope covering digital content and data sales, deeming it inconsistent with their stance against EU overreach into national tax sovereignty and disproportionate targeting of specific business models.  
ECR condemns the issue's unilateral approach as contradictory to their advocacy for OECD-led global solutions, warning it risks retaliatory measures and undermines competitiveness - a stance Ralph Packet explicitly ties to rejecting "European unilateralism".  
ECR objects to the sunset clause linking DST termination to EU tax harmonization measures like CCCTB, viewing this as a backdoor mechanism to centralize fiscal authority against member states' rights.  
ECR disputes the triennial audit mandate as imposing excessive compliance burdens, directly conflicting with their deregulatory agenda and principle that tax administration should remain strictly national.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over tax disparities between traditional and digital companies, proposing to increase the Digital Services Tax (DST) rate from 3% to 5% to address the gap between traditional firms’ effective average tax rate of 20.9% and digital multinationals’ negative average tax rate of -2.3%. The adjustment reflects revised metrics, including aligning implied corporate taxes with the 20% rate paid by traditional firms (instead of the proposed 13%) and assuming a more realistic 25% profit margin for digital businesses (versus 15% in the proposal), given that major firms like Facebook and Google exhibit margins up to 40%. The resolution broadened the DST scope to include revenue from digital content (e.g., video, audio, text), e-commerce transactions, and data sales generated through user interaction on digital interfaces, aiming to counter aggressive tax planning by firms lacking physical presence in Member States. It introduced a sunset clause to phase out the DST upon adoption of permanent EU measures like the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) or a digital significant presence framework. The Commission was urged to review the directive after three years, assessing entities covered, tax distribution across Member States, DST thresholds (revenue and entity size), taxable activities, and audit mechanisms requiring triennial audits of DST returns. These measures aim to ensure equitable taxation and adapt to evolving digital business models.

title: Disclosure of income tax information by certain undertakings and branches: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2013/34/EU as regards disclosure of income tax information by certain undertakings and branches
background: Corporate tax avoidance scandals, including LuxLeaks and Panama Papers, exposed systemic profit-shifting by multinationals, prompting OECD's BEPS framework and EU commitments to fiscal fairness. Growing public demand for accountability and cross-border tax transparency gaps drove regulatory scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing public tax disclosure requirements for large multinational enterprises operating in the EU.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the current proposal as fundamentally inadequate in combating tax avoidance due to the weakened safeguard clause rendering transparency measures ineffective.  
EFDD opposes the issue's hidden harmonization agenda, viewing expanded reporting requirements on third-country operations as incompatible with national sovereignty principles.  
EFDD condemns the maintained €750 million revenue threshold, demanding alignment with their proposed €40 million cap to ensure meaningful SME accountability.  
EFDD rejects the omission of mandatory public disclosure for tax payments in offshore jurisdictions, violating their core transparency demands exposed by Panama Papers revelations.  
EFDD absolutely conflicts bureaucratic reporting burdens that risk deterring foreign investment, contradicting their pro-growth agenda amid post-Brexit economic uncertainties.

GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the issue’s mandate for corporate tax transparency as a vital step toward dismantling systemic inequities between multinationals and SMEs.  
This aligns perfectly with GREEN_EFA’s longstanding commitment to fiscal justice, ensuring all economic actors contribute equitably to societal stability and public services.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the issue’s potential to expose profit-shifting practices that deprive member states of revenue needed for hospitals and social infrastructure.  
The proposal perfectly aligns with GREEN_EFA’s vision of economic democracy, where tax fairness safeguards collective welfare over corporate profit maximization.  
GREEN_EFA unequivocally supports binding transparency measures to end the 1% tax rate scandal, upholding SMEs as the backbone of Europe’s social and economic fabric.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the legislative proposal COM(2016)0198, emphasizing alignment with the OECD’s Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) Action Plan to combat corporate tax avoidance. It acknowledged reasoned opinions from the Irish and Swedish parliaments questioning compliance with subsidiarity principles but proceeded to adopt its position at first reading, urging the Commission to address tax transparency and fair taxation within the EU framework. The resolution stressed the need for coherence with EU legal bases and integration of development policy considerations, as highlighted by the Committee on Development. Parliament instructed the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments are made and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring broader institutional engagement.

title: Double taxation dispute resolution mechanisms in the EU: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive on Double Taxation Dispute Resolution Mechanisms in the European Union
background: Persistent cross-border tax disputes causing double taxation in the EU single market, alongside the 1990 Arbitration Convention's limitations and a 2016 Commission proposal for binding mechanisms, prompted parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss establishing harmonized procedures to resolve double taxation disputes between member states, addressing legal certainty and administrative efficiency for taxpayers.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally upholds the Directive’s unified dispute issue framework, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to fair taxation and eliminating double taxation burdens on businesses.  
EPP applauds the issue’s focus on resolving €10.5 billion in active disputes, reflecting their priority of creating efficient cross-border tax governance structures.  
EPP strongly approves phasing out the 1990 Convention to prioritize modern binding mechanisms, ensuring coherence with EU single market principles.  
EPP commends the transparency measures requiring notification to national parliaments, enhancing accountability in aligning tax policies across Member States.  
EPP recognizes the proposal’s dual approach to combating tax avoidance while protecting against excessive taxation, exemplifying their balanced fairness agenda.

GUE_NGL fundamentally disputes prioritizing double taxation disputes over combating corporate tax evasion, which remains the core threat to fiscal justice in Europe.  
GUE_NGL rejects the asymmetric timelines granting corporations three-year claim windows while restricting states to one-year examinations, entrenching corporate advantage over public interest.  
GUE_NGL condemns any provision allowing immunity for tax crimes during dispute processes, directly contradicting anti-corporate impunity principles.  
GUE_NGL challenges the undemocratic adoption process bypassing parliamentary scrutiny, exemplifying institutional capture by corporate interests.  
GUE_NGL demands full transparency in international tax cases, opposing issue mechanisms maintaining corporate secrecy against public accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0686) to amend double taxation dispute resolution mechanisms, emphasizing compliance with subsidiarity following Sweden’s objection, and approved the amended proposal to strengthen EU-wide coordination. It urged the Commission to revise its proposal under Article 293(2) TFEU and called on the Council to notify Parliament if deviating from the approved text or to reconsult if substantially altering the proposal. Parliament advocated for phasing out the 1990 Convention on double taxation adjustment between associated enterprises to prioritize the Directive’s unified dispute resolution framework, aligning with its 2015 and 2016 resolutions addressing harmful tax practices. The resolution stressed forwarding its position to EU institutions and national parliaments to ensure transparency and coherence in tax dispute resolution.

title: Annual Tax report: REPORT on the Annual Tax Report
background: Ongoing concerns over €1 trillion annual EU tax revenue losses from fraud, avoidance, and aggressive planning, exacerbated by cross-border rulings exposed in LuxLeaks/SwissLeaks, persistent intra-EU tax competition, and OECD BEPS initiatives, prompted scrutiny of systemic vulnerabilities. The Parliament will discuss EU tax policy coordination to address fraud, evasion, and distortions to the internal market.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s call for a mandatory Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base and transparency measures, aligning perfectly with their commitment to dismantling tax advantages for multinational corporations.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the establishment of the special committee on tax rulings, reflecting their 2023 manifesto priority to expose and eliminate aggressive tax planning schemes across the EU.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes environmental tax alignment with climate goals but proposes amending Article 9 to explicitly phase out aviation sector exemptions and redirect fossil fuel subsidies to renewable energy incentives.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the abolition of banking secrecy and urges participating states to expand automatic information exchange to include high-net-worth individuals’ accounts, not solely corporate entities.  
GREEN_EFA approves the VAT gap reforms while emphasizing the need for parallel EU-wide digital service taxes to curb profit shifting by tech giants.

ECR rejects the harmonization of corporate taxation through CCCTB, entirely doubting with their principle of national sovereignty in tax policy and viewing it as a threat to member states' fiscal competitiveness.  
ECR opposes the issue's condemnation of competitive tax regimes, arguing it overlooks how excessive taxation and administrative burdens in other states drive businesses into the shadow economy rather than addressing root causes.  
ECR rejects the proposed VAT system reforms, citing that mechanisms like reverse VAT charges distort the tax's neutrality while failing to curb carousel fraud proliferating across borders.  
ECR entirely doubts with the issue's environmental tax alignment, emphasizing it exacerbates burdens on SMEs and lower-income populations through indirect tax hikes like fuel levies.  
ECR opposes the inadequate targeting of large-scale corporate tax avoidance via intra-group transactions, noting the issue's failure to mandate EU-wide asset registries or smuggling crackdowns critical for Southern Europe.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the annual loss of approximately €1 trillion in EU tax revenue due to tax fraud, evasion, avoidance, and aggressive tax planning, emphasizing the need for coordinated action to combat these practices and ensure fair taxation. It called for swift implementation of the Financial Transaction Tax (FTT) by participating Member States by January 2016, urging others to join, and advocated for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) to harmonize corporate taxation. The resolution highlighted the VAT gap of €177 billion in 2012, urging reforms to simplify VAT systems, reduce administrative burdens, and extend reduced rates to digital media. It stressed the importance of abolishing banking secrecy by June 2015, expanding automatic exchange of tax information globally, and establishing a blacklist of tax havens by June 2015, with sanctions for non-cooperative jurisdictions. The Parliament demanded stricter anti-money laundering rules, mandatory country-by-country reporting for multinationals, and measures to curb profit shifting and harmful tax rulings, including EU state aid investigations. It emphasized the role of SMEs, advocating for reduced tax obstacles and administrative costs, and called for shifting taxation from labor to sustainable sources, aligning environmental taxes with EU climate goals. The resolution also urged integrating tax gap reduction targets into the European Semester, promoting transparency in tax rulings, and enhancing cooperation with international bodies like the OECD and G20 to address base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS).

title: Annual report on EU competition policy: REPORT on the annual report on EU competition policy
background: The EU agricultural sector faced crises, price volatility, and structural supply chain imbalances, with existing competition law derogations underutilized due to legal ambiguities and uneven national enforcement. The Parliament will discuss adapting EU competition policy to agricultural specificities to strengthen market fairness and producer protections.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fundamentally upholds the issue's emphasis on agricultural competition fairness, perfectly aligning with their advocacy for strict antitrust scrutiny of mergers like Bayer-Monsanto to prevent seed monopolies and protect biodiversity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to enforce state aid rules in energy markets, urgently demanding clarity on the Paks nuclear project's compliance with EU competition frameworks to safeguard single market integrity.  
The issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA's digital sovereignty priorities by addressing platform dominance, as exemplified by their push for EU-wide action against booking.com's market distortions in hotel services.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports embedding labor protections in competition policy, echoing Šoltes' demand to combat precarious work through rigorous enforcement against social dumping in transport and digital sectors.  
This aligns perfectly with GREEN_EFA's longstanding commitment to food chain equity through swift implementation of unfair trading practice legislation and sustained Milk Package extensions for dairy farmer resilience.

ECR rejects the issue's approach to state aid compliance as fundamentally challengeing with their demand to end bank bailouts and enforce bail-in mechanisms under the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive.  
ECR opposes tax harmonization efforts cited in the issue, arguing this betrays competition between member states and permanently disadvantages less-developed economies like Croatia.  
ECR fundamentally challenges with environmental regulations in the issue, which they claim disproportionately harm Greek industrial sectors like cement and shipping without global reciprocity.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of national sovereignty by seeking to "embed competition clauses" in trade agreements, which ECR views as centralizing power against member states' fiscal autonomy.  
ECR condemns the issue's failure to address their core principle that "competition among states" must prevail over EU-wide regulatory harmonization in taxation and industrial policy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the insufficient use and clarity of competition law derogations for agricultural producer organizations, hindering their ability to strengthen farmers' positions in the food supply chain and achieve CAP objectives under Article 39 TFEU, particularly in sectors like dairy, olive oil, beef, veal, and arable crops. It urged the Commission to clarify exemptions under Article 101(3) TFEU, enhance legal certainty, and ensure competition policy accounts for agricultural specificities, including triggering Article 222 of the Single CMO Regulation during market crises and extending the "Milk Package" beyond 2020 to improve dairy sector resilience. The resolution emphasized modernizing trade defense instruments to address unfair practices, securing market access in energy, transport, and telecoms, and embedding competition clauses in trade agreements, including state aid rules and provisions against anti-competitive practices by state-owned enterprises. It highlighted the need for fair competition in the digital single market, addressing geo-blocking, data portability under GDPR, and interoperability, while ensuring SME protection and expediting antitrust cases against dominant digital platforms. In transport, Parliament stressed completing the TEN-T network, enforcing fair competition in aviation and road haulage, concluding the Fourth Railway Package, and combating social dumping. It called for EU funds (CEF, Horizon 2020) to support transport infrastructure and urged addressing tax avoidance and state aid non-compliance to ensure a level playing field. The resolution also advocated for EU legislation to tackle unfair trading practices in the food chain, improve collective bargaining for farmers, and address retail sector concentration impacts on innovation and consumer choice, referencing the WTO Nairobi agreement’s export subsidy reductions to enhance agricultural market fairness.

title: Annual report on the financial activities of the European Investment Bank: REPORT on the Annual Report on the financial activities of the European Investment Bank
background: The European Investment Bank, established in 1958, reported €1.1 trillion in cumulative investments by 2017, focusing on EU policy goals like climate action, SME support, and infrastructure. Geopolitical shifts, Brexit’s capital implications, and reliance on USD funding raised operational risks. The Parliament will discuss the EIB’s financial strategy, governance, and alignment with EU priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the EIB’s pivotal role in advancing EU economic priorities, particularly its record €78 billion for innovation and SMEs, aligning perfectly with their commitment to job creation and competitiveness.  
EPP applauds the EIB’s climate leadership, including exceeding its 25% financing target and issuing Sustainability Awareness Bonds, which effectively advances their manifesto goals for the Paris Agreement.  
EPP endorses the issue’s emphasis on reducing dollar-denominated funding risks, proposing enhanced currency diversification strategies to strengthen financial sovereignty.  
EPP highlights the need to expand investments in creative industries and cultural projects as a strategic enhancement opportunity within the EIB’s SME support framework.  
EPP emphasizes safeguarding the EIB’s AAA rating post-Brexit and ensuring equitable solutions for staff, consistent with their focus on institutional resilience.

GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to mandate immediate divestment from fossil fuel infrastructure, which directly contradicts EU 2050 zero-carbon commitments.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the EIB's continued financing of agribusiness giants like Nibulon and MHP, whose industrial practices flood EU markets and undermine ecological family farming.  
GREEN_EFA highlights critical inconsistency in celebrating climate targets while permitting €16.6 billion in 2017 climate financing to coexist with ongoing fossil fuel investments.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's silence on redirecting agricultural loans toward agroecological transitions rather than export-oriented industrial complexes.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding deadlines to eliminate all EIB support for projects incompatible with 1.5°C pathways, absent in current climate "strategic reviews".

resolution: The European Parliament raised the European Investment Bank’s (EIB) 60-year achievements, including €1.1 trillion invested in 11,800 projects across 160 countries, with over 90% of lending within the EU. It highlighted the EIB’s 2017 record of approving 901 projects, including €78 billion for innovation, environment, infrastructure, and SMEs, and noted that 2015-2016 lending within the EU is projected to support €544 billion in investments, adding 2.3% to GDP and creating 2.25 million jobs by 2020. The resolution emphasized the EIB’s role in countering post-crisis investment gaps, with the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) mobilizing €335 billion since 2015, supporting 750,000 jobs and aiming for 1.4 million by 2020. Environmental efforts were underscored, including €16.6 billion in 2017 for climate-related projects, exceeding its 25% climate financing target, and issuing €500 million in Sustainability Awareness Bonds. The EIB’s support for SMEs and mid-caps totaled €29.6 billion in 2017, benefiting 287,000 firms employing 3.9 million people. Parliament urged reduced dollar-denominated funding (33% in 2017) to mitigate sanctions risks and called for enhanced transparency, accountability, and alignment with EU policies like the Paris Agreement and Sustainable Development Goals. It stressed the need for balanced geographical distribution, as 70% of 2017 financing went to six Member States, and supported the Economic Resilience Initiative (€6 billion over five years) for migration-affected regions. Concerns over Brexit included safeguarding the EIB’s AAA rating and equitable solutions for UK staff. The resolution also demanded stricter anti-tax avoidance measures, fossil fuel divestment, and stronger due diligence on intermediaries to prevent fraud and money laundering, while advocating for cross-border projects and deeper cooperation with national promotional banks.

title: Establishing the Fiscalis programme for cooperation in the field of taxation: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the ‘Fiscalis’ programme for cooperation in the field of taxation
